prompt: A musician starts hearing tomorrow's songs on the radio. Write the moment they decide to use this.
story:
The radio crackled awake before dawn, the way it always did when the heat clicked on and off. A blue clock glowed 5:41. Eli lay on his back and listened without listening, thinking about a chorus that wouldn’t settle, when the station cut from static into a song he’d never heard before.

It was a guitar line first, clean and patient, then a voice—his voice. Not exactly, but close enough that his chest tightened. The singer came in half a beat late, the way Eli did when he was tired. The lyrics rhymed in a way he favored, small words turned sideways. He sat up, heart banging. The song had a bridge that dipped and rose like the river by the tracks, and when the chorus returned, it did so with a word change he’d scribbled in a notebook last winter and crossed out.

“This is—” He fumbled for his phone, hit record. The radio announcer cut in, bright and wrong, said the title and the artist’s name. It was his name. Pronounced the way people always got wrong, with a long E instead of a short one.

Eli swung his legs out of bed and stood there, barefoot on cold floorboards, listening to the end of the song as if it were a confession being read aloud. When it finished, the announcer said it would be out tomorrow at midnight, the lead single from an album he hadn’t made.

He laughed, once, sharp. “Okay,” he said to the empty room. The radio went on, into ads. A car dealership. A voice promising low rates. He turned it off.

All day, the song followed him. On the bus to the coffee shop, he heard the bridge again in the squeal of brakes. At the shop, steaming milk, the hiss resolved into the syllables of his name. He told himself it was exhaustion, that the rejection email he’d gotten last night had scrambled something loose. The shop was understaffed; he worked until his wrists ached, then counted tips that smelled like pennies and sugar.

When he got home, the radio was on again. He didn’t remember turning it on.

A different song played. Same voice. Same name announced. This one had a drum pattern he’d never use, too busy, but the melody hooked him anyway. He wrote down the lyrics as they came, hand shaking, as if copying from a dream before it evaporated. The words were better than what he’d been making lately. They were merciless.

He checked the date on his phone, refreshed news, scrolled until his thumb hurt. Nothing. He turned the radio off and on. Same station. The announcer’s time check put it tomorrow. He unplugged the radio. The song kept going for three seconds, then died.

Eli sat on the floor, back against the couch, notebook in his lap, and tried to breathe. He thought of the open mic next week, the way the room thinned out when he played, people nodding politely, waiting for the louder acts. He thought of his mother asking if he’d applied anywhere else yet. He thought of the chorus that wouldn’t settle.

That night, he dreamed of a calendar whose pages turned by themselves, each day humming.

The next morning, he tested it. He left the radio off until noon, then turned it on and waited. The song that came on was the same one from dawn the day before, down to the ad read. The announcer said “out tonight.” Eli checked his phone. It was tonight.

He drove to the record store on Main, the one with the listening station that still had headphones bolted to the counter. The clerk raised an eyebrow when Eli asked if they had the single early. “Midnight,” she said, tapping the register. “You okay?”

At home, he opened his laptop and pulled up his recording software. He listened to the song again on the radio, transcribing chords, tapping tempo. He paused it, rewound in his head, wrote. He sang into the cheap mic, layering harmonies. It came together fast, like he was unearthing something already buried. By evening, he had a rough version. It wasn’t identical; his hands made different choices. But it was close enough that he felt dizzy.

At 11:58, he refreshed the streaming site. Midnight hit. The single appeared under his name, cover art he didn’t recognize. He clicked play. The song unfurled exactly as he’d heard it the day before. Exactly.

He sat back and laughed again, softer this time. “Tomorrow,” he said, and meant more than the day.

The decision came as a small thing, like choosing which mug to use. He opened a new folder and labeled it dates. He tuned the radio to the station and wrote what he heard, not everything, just enough. He told himself he wouldn’t rush, that he’d leave room for himself to be wrong, that he’d change things so it wasn’t theft but collaboration with a future he hadn’t lived yet.

At the open mic, the following week, he played one of the songs. The room didn’t thin. Someone whooped at the bridge. Afterward, a woman with a lanyard asked his name and wrote it down carefully, short E.

That night, back in his apartment, Eli turned the radio on and listened to tomorrow sing. He reached for his notebook, then paused. The song was sad in a way he hadn’t expected. It mentioned a river, a loss. He swallowed.

“I’ll take it slow,” he said aloud, to no one. He wrote the first line anyway.

prompt: A retired detective is asked to solve a case involving a missing recipe book. Make the stakes feel urgent.
story:
The call came while I was pruning the fig tree, my hands sticky with sap and the afternoon quiet enough to hear the flies. I let it ring twice, because retirement is a habit you have to practice. When I answered, my daughter’s voice was tight.

“Dad,” she said. “I need you. Now.”

Marta ran La Caldera, the little place on Alder Street that smelled like cumin and oranges and always had a line out the door. It was her mother’s recipes that did it, written in a green spiral notebook that had been bent and mended and splashed for thirty years. The notebook was missing. Not misplaced—gone.

“I’ve torn the kitchen apart,” Marta said. “We open for the festival tonight. The health inspector is coming because of the pop-up tents. And there’s a food blogger from Chicago who just walked in and asked for the bacalao.”

I wiped my hands on my jeans and felt the old click in my head. “Who was in the kitchen last night?”

“Me. Luis. The dishwasher. And that new sous, Evan.” She hesitated. “Dad, the notebook has allergy notes. Substitutions. It’s not just flavors. It’s safety.”

I drove downtown with the windows down, letting the smell of hot asphalt pull me back. La Caldera was a brick shoebox, its windows fogged with steam and garlic. Marta met me by the prep table, eyes ringed with flour. The kitchen was chaos held together by muscle memory.

I asked to see where the book lived. She pointed to a shelf above the spice rack, the wood worn smooth by hands. The space was empty. A smudge of green paint marked where the cover used to lean.

“Anyone angry? Anyone desperate?” I asked.

She snorted. “Welcome to food service.”

I talked to Luis, who shrugged and said he’d been drunk on Fernet and gone by nine. The dishwasher said nothing at all, which is its own kind of truth. Evan was tall, clean, nervous. He said he admired Marta’s mother, said he’d learned to cook from books too. His knife roll was neat as a surgeon’s kit.

“Did you take the notebook?” I asked him.

He flushed. “No. Why would I?”

Because recipes are currency, I thought. Because you’re new and hungry.

I asked to see the office. Marta led me past the walk-in to a narrow room with a desk and a corkboard of old photos. The safe was open. Cash untouched. No forced entry anywhere. The book hadn’t walked out in a pocket by accident; it was thick, swollen with clippings.

I stood in the kitchen and listened. The sizzle, the clatter, the low Spanish and English. Urgency has a sound. It’s the pitch of a room leaning forward.

“What if we close?” Marta said quietly.

“You can’t,” I said. “Not tonight.”

I went back to the shelf and pulled spices down, sniffing. Paprika. Coriander. Cinnamon. On the wall beside the shelf was a menu chalked in Marta’s hand. A new dish circled twice. Bacalao al pil-pil. Traditional. Fussy. The kind of thing you don’t improvise if you respect your elders.

“Who suggested the bacalao?” I asked.

“Evan,” she said. “He said it would impress.”

I asked Evan to show me how he’d make it. He spoke quickly, hands moving. Olive oil, garlic, cod, emulsify with gelatin from the skin. He paused when I asked about substitutions for gelatin.

“There aren’t any,” he said.

“There are,” I said. “If you know the tricks. And if you know the allergies of the people you feed.”

I went outside. The festival tents were going up, white and hopeful. I watched Evan through the window, the way his eyes went to the shelf. The way his shoulders eased when he thought no one was watching.

I remembered my own hunger, years ago, the way you can convince yourself that borrowing is different from stealing if you plan to return the thing richer. I went back in and asked Marta for the old bread oven key.

The oven sat cold in the corner, used for storage now. Inside were sheet pans and a cardboard box of menus from last year. Beneath them, wrapped in a towel, was the green notebook. The cover was smeared with oil. Pages stuck together at the corner, a fresh stain.

I took it to Marta. She exhaled like she’d been underwater.

We confronted Evan in the alley. He cried. He said he’d copied some pages, that he’d meant no harm, that he wanted to learn. He said he’d hidden it when he heard the inspector was coming, panicked, thought he could put it back later.

“You didn’t read the notes,” Marta said, flipping pages. “My mother wrote that this dish is deadly for Mr. Alvarez’s grandson. He’s coming tonight.”

The color drained from Evan’s face. The urgency sharpened into something with teeth.

Marta closed the book. The kitchen found its rhythm again. She adjusted the menu. The blogger ate something else and wrote a paragraph about restraint.

At closing, Marta poured me a small glass of sherry. “Stay,” she said. “In case something else goes missing.”

I shook my head. Retirement is a habit you have to practice. Outside, the fig tree waited, and the city breathed.

prompt: A child discovers a map drawn in invisible ink on their own skin. What does it lead to?
story:
The map showed itself the day the power went out.

Milo had been sitting on the bathroom floor, legs crossed, flashlight clenched between his teeth, watching his breath fog in the cold. The storm had knocked out the lines, and the house had gone quiet in the way that made every creak sound like a footstep. He shone the beam on his arm to check a scrape from earlier, and that was when the lines bloomed.

They weren’t scars. They were thin, brownish strokes, like someone had drawn on him with a very fine pen and then tried to wash it away. The lines curved and forked, made a shape he recognized without knowing why.

A map.

Milo dropped the flashlight. It clattered and rolled, throwing light across the tile. The lines faded as the beam skittered away. He brought the light back, slower this time. The lines returned, darkening where the beam lingered.

His heart started to knock.

He turned his arm, then his wrist. The lines continued, breaking and resuming like streets interrupted by rivers. On his palm, a small circle sat at the base of his thumb. On his forearm, a longer line ran straight as if someone had used a ruler.

Milo remembered something his mother used to say when he was smaller, when he asked about the faint marks on his skin. Everyone’s got maps on them, she’d say, kissing his knuckles. You just have to know how to read them.

She had been gone a year now. The house still smelled like her soap when it rained.

He spent the rest of the night with the flashlight, tracing the lines across himself. They climbed his arms, crossed his collarbone, dipped along his ribs. When he turned the beam on his back, using the mirror, there were more lines there, fainter, like roads no one used anymore. On his left shoulder blade was a triangle. On his right hip, another circle.

By morning, when the power hummed back on and the sun filled the bathroom, the lines vanished. His skin looked like skin again.

Milo pulled on a hoodie and went outside.

The neighborhood was still wet from the storm. Branches littered the sidewalks. He walked to the corner where Maple met Third, then stopped. The shape of the intersection tugged at him. He rolled up his sleeve, even though the sun made the lines shy. There—on his arm—the same forked curve.

He followed it.

As he walked, he matched street to skin. The long straight line on his forearm was Maple itself, running past the closed bakery and the park where the swings creaked in the wind. The small circle on his palm was the roundabout by the library. The triangle on his shoulder blade—he turned and craned to see—was the old water tower on the hill.

By the time he reached the edge of town, his legs ached. The houses thinned, replaced by weeds and gravel. The map on his skin grew clearer as clouds slid over the sun, as if it preferred dimness. He crossed the tracks, heart pounding, and climbed the path that led into the woods.

The woods smelled like mushrooms and wet leaves. The path narrowed. He slipped once, caught himself on a tree. His sleeve snagged, tore. The lines on his arm glowed softly, as if pleased.

He came to a clearing he hadn’t known was there. In the center was a stone well, its rim slick with moss. A rope lay coiled beside it, frayed but whole.

The circle on his palm burned.

Milo approached the well. He leaned over and shone his flashlight down. The beam caught water far below, black and still. He couldn’t see the bottom.

“Hello?” he called, feeling foolish.

Something answered. Not a voice. A ripple.

He dropped the rope. It unwound and slid into the dark. When it went taut, he counted the knots as he pulled it back up. The rope was wet. At the end was a small metal box, dented and rusted.

His fingers shook as he pried it open.

Inside were photographs, curled and stuck together. A woman with dark hair holding a baby. The same woman laughing, older, beside a man Milo didn’t recognize. A house that wasn’t theirs, with a blue door. Under the photos was a folded piece of paper, edges softened by water.

Milo smoothed it out. The handwriting was his mother’s.

If you find this, it said, then it’s time.

The map was always there. On me, first. Then on you. I didn’t know where it led until I followed it. It leads to what we leave behind and what we carry forward. It leads to the place where you choose.

Milo sat back on his heels. The woods breathed around him.

He rolled up his sleeves, pulled up his shirt. The lines on his skin were changing. Where they had once run outward, they now curved inward, converging. The circle on his palm was fading, replaced by a new mark at the center of his chest, faint as a bruise.

He understood then that the map had not led him to the well, not really. The well was a point, a pause. The map led him here to this moment, where the past waited to be acknowledged and then released.

Milo gathered the photos and the letter. He closed the box and left it by the well, placing the rope neatly beside it. When he stood, the lines on his skin had almost vanished, like ink washed by rain.

He turned back toward town. The path seemed clearer now, wider. As he walked, he felt a warmth spread through him, as if something long folded had finally been unfolded.

At the edge of the woods, he paused and looked back. The clearing was already hard to see, swallowed by leaves and shadow.

Milo went home, carrying nothing in his hands, the map gone from his skin, but knowing the way.

prompt: A botanist wakes to find every plant in the city whispering a different rumor. Write the first day she decides to listen.
story:
She woke to the sound of leaves clearing their throats.

It wasn’t a sound, exactly. More like a pressure behind the ears, a sifting of syllables the way wind sifts sand. Lina Calder lay still in her apartment, eyes open, breath shallow. The ficus in the corner—the one she’d rescued from a dentist’s office dumpster—rustled though the windows were closed.

“…told you she’d wake,” it murmured, or maybe she murmured it to herself. Lina pressed her palms to her eyes. The ceiling fan hummed. Somewhere a bus sighed to a stop. The city was ordinary except for the undercurrent, a thousand tiny voices threading through the morning like mycelium.

She swung her legs out of bed. The basil on the windowsill smelled sharp, green, offended. “They’re late again,” it said, petulant. “Sun’s been up for minutes.” The aloe beside it whispered a different tone, conspiratorial: “Don’t trust the water. Pipes remember things.”

Lina laughed once, too loudly. She was a botanist. She knew stress dreams. She knew the way the mind filled silence with patterns. She also knew the exact watering schedule of her plants, their Latin names, the way basil leaves go limp when thirsty and aloe does not. She pulled on jeans and a sweater and made coffee. The coffee plant on the shelf—an experiment, never fruiting—sighed. “Wasteful,” it said. “Boiling beans of my cousins.”

By the time she stepped onto the street, she was shaking.

The sycamores lining the block were awake, leaves clapping softly. “New landlord’s lying,” one said. “Says he won’t cut us.” A dandelion pushing through a crack in the sidewalk hissed, “They salt the roads too much. Burned my sister last winter.” The ivy crawling up a brick wall gossiped in a dozen overlapping voices about a cat that hunted birds and a window where someone cried at night.

Lina walked fast, as if speed might outrun sound. Her phone buzzed with a text from her sister—coffee later?—and the grass at the corner lot snickered, “She’ll cancel. She always does.” Lina stopped short. The grass had no way of knowing that. She swallowed.

At the bus stop, a potted fern drooped in a cracked ceramic bowl, abandoned by a shop that had closed. “Take me,” it said, not pleading so much as stating a fact. “I don’t belong to anyone anymore.” Lina crouched, fingers hovering. The bus roared up, doors wheezing. She stood, heart pounding, and left the fern behind. The fern did not reproach her. It simply began to hum, low and patient.

At the university greenhouse, the noise was a cathedral. Glass amplified everything. Orchids traded rumors of infidelity among the grad students. The carnivorous plants were blunt. “Feed us better,” they snapped. “You owe us.” The cycads spoke slowly, in sentences that felt like tectonic plates shifting. “This city is young,” they said. “It forgets the floods.”

Lina’s supervisor, Dr. Menon, waved from across the room, mouth moving. Lina watched the words form without sound, the way you watch fish mouths open and close. She nodded, smiled, and escaped to the propagation room. The door shut and the whispers dulled to a manageable murmur.

She pressed her back to the cool metal shelf and slid down until she was sitting on the floor among trays of seedlings. Her hands were steady now. That surprised her. Panic had burned itself out, leaving a clean, bright attention behind.

She thought of the papers she’d read on plant signaling—volatile compounds, electrical impulses, the way roots communicated through fungi. She thought of old stories her grandmother told about trees that remembered names. She thought of rumors as a kind of data, noisy and biased and alive.

A tray of tomato seedlings leaned toward her. “The tomatoes in the cafeteria are sick,” they said. “Something in the soil.” Another tray whispered, “The janitor waters us at night and sings.”

Lina laughed again, softer. She took out her notebook. On the first page she wrote the date. On the second, she wrote: Listen.

She spent the afternoon walking. She skipped meetings. She followed the map of sound: to the park where the oaks argued about lightning scars and the roses bragged about thorns; to the river where reeds shivered with talk of oil slicks upstream; to a vacant lot where milkweed plotted a monarch’s return. She learned to tell the difference between fear and gossip, between a warning and a wish.

At dusk she went back for the fern at the bus stop. It was still there, leaves dulled by exhaust. “You came,” it said, mildly surprised. She carried it home on the bus, ignoring the looks. The fern whispered directions—more light, less water—and a rumor about a cracked window on the third floor where a sparrow nested.

In her apartment, she set the fern by the window and opened it a crack. The city settled into evening. The whispers softened, like people lowering their voices when someone starts to listen.

Lina sat on the floor with her back against the wall, notebook open, pen poised. Tomorrow, she would tell someone. Or maybe she wouldn’t. Today was for listening, for learning the difference between noise and need. The basil sighed, content now. The ficus rustled approval. Outside, the sycamores leaned together, passing along the news that a woman had finally heard them.

prompt: Write a scene where two rivals are trapped in an elevator during a blackout. Their conversation changes everything.
story:
The elevator shuddered once, sighed, and stopped between floors with a gentle thud that felt anything but gentle. The lights went out. Emergency bulbs blinked on, a sickly amber that made skin look bruised.

“Perfect,” Mara said. “Just perfect.”

Evan stood with one hand still hovering near the button he’d pressed—twenty-two, his floor, her floor too—like a child caught stealing. He exhaled slowly. “It’s a blackout. We’ll be fine.”

“Easy for you to say,” she snapped. “You don’t have a presentation in fifteen minutes.”

He laughed before he could stop himself. “You mean the one you stole from my team?”

She turned, the small light catching the sharp line of her jaw. “I improved it.”

“You rebranded it,” he said. “There’s a difference.”

The elevator hummed, then went quiet. The building felt hollow without its usual thrum. Somewhere far below, a siren wailed and cut off.

Mara pressed the call button. Nothing. She hit it again, harder. “Of course.”

Evan leaned against the wall, careful to keep space between them. It was ridiculous how much he still felt her presence—like a magnet, repelling and pulling at the same time. “Emergency line probably needs power.”

She slid down the wall until she was sitting, knees up. Her heels clicked softly against the metal. “We can’t be stuck. Not today.”

“Why today?” he asked, before thinking.

She looked at him, eyes bright with a frustration that was too sharp for the situation. “Because if I win this account, it proves I didn’t need you. And if I lose, everyone will say—”

“That you did,” he finished.

The words hung there. He hadn’t meant to say them. He hadn’t meant to sound tired.

Mara stared at the opposite wall. “I didn’t steal your idea, Evan.”

He snorted. “Right.”

“I didn’t,” she said again, louder. “I took the job. I took the client. I took the promotion you wanted. But the idea? That was always going to be what it was. We were circling the same thing.”

“Funny,” he said. “It looked exactly like my pitch.”

“It looked like the future,” she shot back. “And if you’d stopped trying to own it, you’d see that.”

Silence pressed in, thicker than the dim light. The elevator creaked, settling. Evan became acutely aware of the smallness of the space, the smell of metal and her citrus perfume. His heart thudded. He hated that she still knew how to make him feel twelve things at once.

“Why did you leave?” he asked suddenly.

Mara laughed, short and humorless. “You’re asking me that now?”

“We have time,” he said, gesturing vaguely. “Apparently.”

She closed her eyes. When she opened them, something had shifted. “I left because you wouldn’t listen. Because every meeting turned into a competition you had to win. Because when my mother got sick, you told me to ‘power through.’”

He swallowed. He remembered saying it. He remembered thinking it was supportive.

“I didn’t know it sounded like that,” he said.

“It sounded like you,” she said. “Brilliant. Exhausting. Certain.”

He slid down the wall opposite her, knees bent, mirroring her posture without meaning to. “I was scared.”

She frowned. “Of what?”

“Of being ordinary,” he said. “Of being wrong. Of losing you.”

Her breath caught, just slightly. “You lost me anyway.”

“I know.”

The emergency light flickered. Somewhere, water began to drip rhythmically, like a clock.

Mara rubbed her hands together. “There’s something you should know,” she said.

His stomach tightened. “Okay.”

She took a breath. “I didn’t win the client yet.”

He blinked. “What?”

“They’re deciding today. Between us.” She met his eyes. “And I didn’t improve your pitch. I changed the part you didn’t see.”

He leaned forward. “What part?”

“The ethics review,” she said. “The data sourcing. The thing that would get us sued in a year.”

He stared at her. He thought of the rushed meetings, the corners cut. He thought of how sure he’d been. “I didn’t—”

“I know,” she said gently. “That’s why I left. Because I kept catching those things, and you kept telling me not to slow you down.”

The elevator jolted, just enough to make Mara gasp and Evan reach out, his hand closing around her wrist. Her skin was warm. They froze, aware of the contact. He didn’t let go.

“If you present that,” he said slowly, “you’ll beat me.”

She nodded. “Yes.”

“And you’re telling me because…?”

“Because being right doesn’t feel like winning anymore,” she said. “And because if I do this alone, it proves all the wrong things.”

The lights flickered again. Then, with a hum that sounded like a held breath released, the elevator began to descend.

Evan loosened his grip but didn’t pull away. “If we combine,” he said, the idea forming as he spoke, “your revision and my model—”

“We could make it solid,” she finished. “And faster.”

The elevator slowed. Stopped. The doors slid open onto a dim hallway filled with emergency lights and murmurs of people.

Mara stood. Evan did too. For a moment, they were just two figures in amber light, rivals on the edge of something unnamed.

“Coffee after?” he asked.

She hesitated, then smiled—not sharp, not victorious, but real. “We have a presentation,” she said. “Together.”

They stepped out of the elevator side by side, the blackout behind them, the building waiting.

prompt: The last public library on earth is floating on a barge. Describe a day when a storm forces it to dock.
story:
The last public library on earth rode low in the water, its barge belly full of paper and patience. It drifted the old shipping lanes because the rivers were calmer than cities, and because the cities no longer wanted it. On clear days the windows caught the sun and the letters painted on the hull—PUBLIC—faded but legible, could be read from a mile away.

That morning the sky had the color of a bruise. The librarian, Mara, woke to the sound of the anchor chain complaining as it lifted and dropped in short, nervous jerks. She stood in the narrow galley, bracing herself with one hand while the kettle skittered like a live thing. The weather band crackled on the radio: pressure falling, winds up, a storm moving fast along the coast. She poured water down the sink, watched it swirl, and thought of how storms used to be something you read about—names and dates and deadliness contained between covers.

They were open to the public from sunrise to sunset, wherever they happened to be. Today they were open to the storm.

By midmorning, the river had grown teeth. Waves slapped the barge’s steel sides, rattling the shelves. The books had been chained in place after a bad crossing years ago, thin cables threaded through the spines’ back edges, a compromise between freedom and survival. Mara walked the aisles with a roll of tape and a hand on the rail that ran the length of the floor. She checked the children’s section—thinner books, more color, more danger of becoming confetti—and tightened a strap.

The first visitor arrived just as the sky tore open. A fisherman in a yellow slicker clambered up the ladder, rain slicking off him in sheets. He stamped his boots and smiled apologetically. “Thought I’d be late,” he said, voice raised over the wind. “But I guess you can’t float away today.”

Mara smiled back. “Storm’s not a reason to close,” she said, because she had said it a thousand times. “It’s a reason to read.”

He took a seat by the window, opened a book about whales, and leaned his forehead to the glass as if listening for something older than the weather.

The barometer dropped. The river rose. By noon, it was clear the barge would have to dock. The anchor would not hold; the current had begun to drag them sideways, toward a bend where the pilings were old and the water chewed them. The radio crackled again, and the voice on the other end was more urgent now, a harbor master who knew them by call sign and by heart. “You’ve got to tie up,” he said. “Now.”

Mara rang the bell. It was an old brass thing salvaged from a schoolhouse, and its sound was both command and comfort. “We’re docking,” she announced. “Please hold the rails.”

They maneuvered toward the pier, the engine laboring. The storm wrapped itself around the barge like a wet sheet, slapping, pulling, insisting. The fisherman helped with the lines, his hands sure. Two teenagers who had come aboard earlier to charge their phones—no one ever turned them away—held ropes and laughed with the thin bravado of youth. The barge bumped, once, twice, then settled, lines taut, a temporary peace.

The pier was not meant for libraries. It smelled of diesel and rust, and a warehouse loomed, its windows blind. The rain came down harder, flattening the river into hammered metal. Inside, the library felt suddenly smaller, contained by land. The sense of drift was gone; in its place was a weight, a pause.

People came because the storm made them. A woman with a baby pressed to her chest, both wrapped in plastic; an old man who said he used to work here, when here was a town with a name; a boy who ran all the way from the warehouses, his hair plastered to his skull. They shook off water and took seats. They watched the shelves as if expecting them to speak.

Mara stood at the desk and felt the day change. Docking was always like this: the world leaning in. “If you need anything,” she said. “Stories, maps, instructions.”

The old man asked for newspapers, any year. He wanted to see a day when the weather was ordinary. The woman asked for something to read aloud. The boy asked if there were books about storms. Mara handed them what she could. Her hands knew the shelves better than her eyes; she could find a thing by weight.

As the storm raged, the building creaked. A leak appeared near the atlas case, a thin line of water tracing continents on the floor. They put a bucket under it. The sound of drops was a metronome.

At three, the power went. The lights flickered and died, leaving the gray of afternoon and the yellow of emergency lamps. Phones went dark. The library breathed. Mara lit lanterns and set them on tables. Shadows climbed the spines.

She read then, because sometimes reading aloud was the only way to hold a room together. She chose something small and sturdy, a poem about a harbor and a hand on a rope. Her voice found its place between the thunder and the rain. The baby slept. The fisherman closed his eyes. The boy leaned forward.

When the storm passed—as storms do, with a suddenness that feels like mercy—the river was changed. Debris bobbed. The air smelled rinsed. The harbor master’s voice returned, calmer. “You can untie when you’re ready.”

Mara waited. Docking had brought them people, and people had brought them the reason. As the sun dipped, she watched the last visitor leave, a book under his arm stamped with a return date that meant nothing now and everything later. She untied the lines with the fisherman’s help. The barge slid free, the river taking it back.

Behind them, the pier stood empty. Ahead, the water opened. The library floated on, lights warm against the dark, carrying what could still be shared, because it had docked when it had to, and because it had not stayed.

prompt: A chef can taste emotions in food. Show how this ability complicates a dinner party.
story:
By the time the guests arrived, Mara’s mouth already felt bruised. She’d been tasting all afternoon—spoon to lips, rinse, repeat—each bite a bright smear of feeling. The onions had been chopped with impatience, sharp and metallic. The bread dough rose with a shy hopefulness, yeasty and warm. She tried to hum as she worked, to keep her own temper from seeping into the food like ink in water.

The doorbell rang. Mara wiped her hands and opened the door to a tide of coats and perfume and laughter. This dinner mattered. It was meant to be a celebration: her partner, Jonah, had just landed a grant, and they were hosting their closest circle. Mara had chosen a menu she thought would behave—simple, comforting, familiar.

As they settled into the living room with wine, Mara retreated to the kitchen. The soup simmered, steam carrying up the smell of leeks and thyme. She tasted. Contentment. Relief. The kind of calm that comes after a long walk. Good.

“Smells incredible,” Jonah said, leaning against the counter. He kissed her cheek. She tasted him—on his breath, a quick note of nerves beneath the wine. He was worried. About the grant? About something else?

She smiled and handed him a spoon. “Tell me what you think.”

He sipped. His eyes softened. “It tastes like Sunday.”

Mara laughed. She could live with that.

At the table, the guests took their seats. Lila, Jonah’s sister, perched near the end, checking her phone with a twitchy thumb. Tomas and Elise arrived last, flushed from the cold, bickering softly about parking. There were others—neighbors, colleagues—but Mara’s attention snagged on those three. She ladled soup, moving clockwise, careful to keep her face neutral.

Lila’s bowl carried a faint bitterness, a tannic edge that made Mara’s jaw tighten. Envy, old and vinegary. It clung to the potatoes. Lila smiled too brightly. “Congratulations,” she said to Jonah, lifting her spoon. “You deserve it.”

Tomas’s soup was brittle with resentment, like overcooked greens. Elise’s was hollow, a watery absence that made Mara’s throat ache. She had to swallow hard after tasting each one, the flavors of feeling stacking up like plates she couldn’t clear.

Conversation bobbed along. People praised the soup. Mara nodded and sipped water. The wine tasted like anticipation and gossip. She focused on the bread basket, tearing a roll and chewing to ground herself. Bread always helped.

The main course was chicken with lemon and capers, roasted vegetables, a bright salad. She plated carefully, breathing slow. As she carried dishes out, she caught fragments of talk.

“…committee was split,” someone said.

“…thought you two were solid,” another murmured.

Mara set a plate in front of Elise. The chicken on that plate tasted of grief, sudden and saline, like tears swallowed. Elise’s smile trembled as she thanked her. Across from her, Tomas speared a carrot with unnecessary force. His food buzzed with anger, a crackle that made Mara’s tongue prickle.

“Everything okay?” Jonah asked, noticing Mara’s pause.

“Fine,” she said. It came out thin.

Halfway through the meal, Lila set her fork down. “So,” she said lightly, “now that you’re flush with grant money, maybe you can help Mom with the roof.”

The table stilled. Jonah’s jaw tightened. The chicken on his plate shifted in Mara’s mouth, souring with defensiveness.

“We’ve talked about this,” Jonah said. “It’s earmarked.”

Lila’s laugh was brittle. The bitterness flared. “Right. Of course.”

Mara’s head swam. Emotions collided—envy, anger, grief—turning the room hot. She tasted Elise’s plate again, an undertow of sadness that pulled at her. Without thinking, she said, “Elise, do you want to talk about it?”

Elise looked up, startled. Tomas stiffened. “Talk about what?”

Silence spread, thick as gravy. Mara’s heart thudded. She’d broken her rule. She never named what she tasted. People didn’t like being told what they felt.

Elise’s eyes filled. “We lost the baby,” she said, the words tumbling out. “Last week.”

Tomas pushed back his chair. “We didn’t agree—”

Elise stood. “I can’t sit here pretending everything is fine.” She pressed a napkin to her mouth and fled toward the bathroom.

The table erupted into apologies and excuses. Lila stared at her plate. Jonah reached for Mara’s hand under the table, his palm damp.

“I’m sorry,” Mara whispered.

The rest of the meal limped on. Food cooled. Words were chosen like stepping stones over a river. When dessert came—a pear tart glazed with honey—Mara hesitated. She tasted the tart. Relief, gentle and amber. She’d made it early, before the guests arrived, before the room filled with its crosscurrents.

She served it. The first bites were quiet. Then Lila sighed. “This,” she said softly, “this is really good.”

Tomas’s shoulders eased a fraction. Elise returned, eyes red, and took a forkful. The grief remained, but it was wrapped now in care, in the steady sweetness of being held without questions.

After the guests left, the kitchen was a wreck of plates and crumbs. Jonah leaned against the counter, watching Mara scrape leftovers into containers.

“You didn’t mean to,” he said.

She rinsed her hands, the water cold. “I did. I tasted it, and I spoke.”

He kissed her temple. His taste was steadier now. “Maybe that’s what dinners are for.”

Mara packed the remaining tart away, careful to label it. Tomorrow, alone, it would taste like quiet. Tonight, she closed the fridge and let the door seal, keeping the flavors where they belonged.

prompt: In a world where rain never stops, a dry room is found. Who claims it first, and why?
story:
The rain had been falling since before anyone could remember the sound of a door closing without a wet slap. It fell straight down when the wind was tired and sideways when the wind was angry, and it threaded itself through every seam the city had. It slicked the stone and ate the mortar, it bloomed mushrooms in pockets of shade, it softened voices and erased chalk. People learned to live with it by moving higher, by sealing what they could, by keeping their papers wrapped in oilskin and their bones wrapped in wool.

Lio worked below, where the rain was worst.

He was an undertaker in the old quarter, which meant he handled bodies that had soaked too long and names written in inks that bled into anonymity. He wore boots with nails through the soles and a coat stitched from tarred canvas, and his hands smelled of lye. The dead came to him in barges, their eyes closed against water they no longer felt. His job was to wash them clean, to tag them, to lay them out so families could recognize them before the city took them to the river crypts.

It was while he was hauling a coffin cart through a collapsed service tunnel that he found the room.

The tunnel had been mapped as flooded for years. The rain roared in the drains and leaked through the ceiling in threads that never paused. Lio took a wrong turn to avoid a cave-in and pushed through a door that should have opened to water. Instead, the hinges groaned and then swung into silence.

The room was dry.

Not damp. Not merely less wet. Dry, the way bread goes stale and lips crack. Dust lay undisturbed on shelves. The air felt thin and sharp in his lungs. A single bulb hung from the ceiling, unlit, and below it a table stood with four legs solid on a floor that had never known a puddle.

Lio stood there a long moment, rain pounding the door behind him, listening to his own breath. His coat steamed. He reached out and touched the table. His finger came away clean.

He backed out, shut the door, and leaned his forehead against the cool metal, feeling a fear he hadn’t known in years. Dryness was dangerous. Dryness invited fire and rot of a different kind. Dryness was a lie the city told children in stories.

By the time he wheeled the body to the mortuary, he had decided what to do.

The mortuary was a warren of rooms that smelled of vinegar and soap. He laid the man out, peeled back the shroud, and saw the name tag had bled into nothing. The family would not recognize him. They would weep for a shape.

Lio went to the office where the ledger lay under a glass case. The pages were wavy with age. He took a pen and hesitated. The ink trembled at the nib, ready to run.

He closed the book.

At dawn—if dawn could be called a lightening of the rain—Lio went to the city clerk. The clerk sat in a cubicle of tin and glass with water running down the walls like veins. She wore rubber gloves and an expression of practiced patience.

“I need to file a claim,” Lio said.

“For what?” she asked, without looking up.

“A room.”

She snorted. “Everything is a room if you stack it right.”

“This one is dry.”

Her pen paused. She looked up. “Say that again.”

He did. He told her where, beneath the old service tunnels, past the third rusted valve and the fallen sign. He told her how the door sealed, how the dust lay. He watched her eyes change, sharpen.

She stood and called her supervisor. A man in a slicker came, then another. They talked in low voices. Someone laughed, sharp and nervous.

“You can’t keep it,” the supervisor said finally. “Dry spaces are municipal assets.”

“I didn’t ask to keep it,” Lio said. “I’m claiming first use.”

“For what purpose?”

He thought of the ledger, of names washed away. He thought of families clutching hats and scarves, squinting at faces blurred by water. He thought of the way paper buckled and tore.

“To lay out the dead,” he said. “To write their names where they won’t run.”

There was a silence broken by the rain’s steady drumming. The clerk tapped her pen.

“Dryness attracts attention,” the supervisor said. “Others will want it. Engineers. Archivists. Priests.”

“I know,” Lio said. “I’ll lock it. I’ll guard it. I’ll let them in when I’m done.”

“And when are you done with the dead?” the clerk asked softly.

Lio looked at her hands, the way the water slid off her gloves. “When the rain stops.”

They escorted him back with two guards. The door opened again on the impossible air. The guards stepped in, boots echoing. One of them laughed and stamped his foot, then stopped, as if ashamed.

Word traveled fast, as it always did in a city with nowhere to hide. By noon there were people waiting when Lio unlocked the door again: a woman with a bundle of papers wrapped in cloth, a man with a matchbook he held like contraband, a boy whose hair was always plastered flat.

Lio took the first body down and laid it on the table. He dried the man’s face with a cloth that stayed dry. He wrote the name in ink that held its shape.

Outside, the rain did not falter. Inside, the room held.

When others pressed him—offered coins, favors, prayers—he shook his head. “After,” he said. “After.”

He claimed the room not because it was precious, though it was, but because in a world where everything ran, someone had to hold fast.

prompt: A florist is asked to create a bouquet for a funeral on Mars. Describe the choices they make.
story:
The request came through the relay at dawn, when the shop’s humidity lamps were still warming and the leaves were furled tight like green fists. “Funeral bouquet,” the text read. “Mars. Departure in eight sols.”

I stared at the word Mars until it lost its shape. I’d arranged weddings in orbit, anniversaries on lunar hotels, a christening that drifted because the parents wanted the baby to float through gypsophila. But Mars had rules. Everything there did.

I pulled on my gloves and stepped between the benches. The air smelled like wet stone and sap. Earth flowers were indulgent things, with wide faces and a hunger for gravity. Mars didn’t have the patience. I began by listing constraints on the slate: mass, dehydration tolerance, radiation hardiness, pollen containment. A bouquet for a funeral had to survive the long cold burn and then say something when it arrived.

The deceased was a hydrogeologist, the message added, forty-three, first generation. Memorial in Ares City’s greenhouse dome. That told me something about the audience: people who knew the cost of water, who had learned to love green things with a ferocity born of scarcity.

I chose rosemary first. Not the potted, bushy rosemary we sold to kitchens, but the narrow-leafed cultivar that thrived on neglect. Rosemary remembered. It dried into itself without losing scent, the oils locking in like a story told softly but never forgotten. It had been used at funerals before Mars was even a word anyone could pronounce without myth. I clipped sprigs and weighed them, shaving grams where I could.

Then I considered roses and rejected them. Too thirsty, too loud. Mars wanted quieter symbols. I reached for statice, the papery kind that crackled when you brushed it. It would hold color through vacuum and time. The violet would read as grief without shouting. I added three stems.

For the anchor, I chose a small branch of olive, grown under LED suns that mimicked Mediterranean mornings. Olive spoke of peace, of endurance. It also had a geometry that felt right for Mars: narrow leaves, silvery undersides that caught light like frost.

I hesitated over color. Reds would echo the planet, but red flowers bled into cliché there. Everyone wore red dust; it was in their boots, their lungs, their dreams. I settled on white accents—waxflower buds like stars, unopened, patient. They would open, maybe, under the dome. Or they wouldn’t. Either way, they would be honest.

The stems needed to be bound without water. I used a biodegradable gel wrap, thin as onion skin, infused with nutrients that released slowly. The knot mattered. Too tight and you bruised the stems. Too loose and the bouquet would shudder itself apart during transit. I tied with flax twine and sealed the knot with beeswax, warmed by my thumb.

While I worked, I thought about my mother, who had never left Earth and who had taught me the difference between arranging for the living and arranging for the dead. “For the living, you give them what they want,” she said, tucking fern around peonies. “For the dead, you give them what they deserve.”

What did a hydrogeologist on Mars deserve? Water was a miracle there, a negotiation with the planet. I added a vial. Not glass—too risky—but a clear polymer tube no bigger than my finger, sealed and labeled. Inside, ten milliliters of water from Earth, distilled, with a single drop of salt. Tears had salt, my mother had said once, when she thought I wasn’t listening. The vial would be tethered with filament, swinging gently like a pendulum.

Before sealing the shipment, I placed a seed packet beneath the stems. Native Earth wildflowers, mixed. It was a small rebellion. Officially, Martian horticulture favored controlled genomes. But funerals were thresholds, and thresholds invited risks. If the family chose to plant them in the dome’s margins, perhaps a corner would surprise someone years from now.

The courier drone arrived with a whisper. I slid the bouquet into its cradle and felt the finality of the latch. Eight sols. The shop felt suddenly empty, the benches too wide.

Three weeks later, a message came back. Not a thank-you, but a clip. The bouquet lay on a stone plinth under the dome. Light filtered through curved glass, catching on the olive leaves. People stood in a half-circle, boots dusted red. Someone leaned in and touched the rosemary, inhaled, and closed their eyes. The waxflower buds had opened, improbably, tiny white stars against the green.

At the end of the clip, the camera panned down. The vial swung, barely moving. A child reached out and steadied it with one finger.

I watched it twice more before returning to my benches. There were orders waiting: a birthday, an apology, a grand opening. I misted the leaves and felt the old, simple joy of coaxing life into form. Somewhere, on a planet that asked for patience and offered little back, a few Earth-born stems were doing what flowers had always done: holding grief long enough for people to set it down.

prompt: A spacecraft returns to Earth after 200 years, but its crew insists it was only weeks. Explore the mismatch.
story:
The spacecraft came down in the dry basin where a lake used to be, its hull scarred like a burned coin. The landing gear punched into dust and old plastics, and the air around it smelled faintly of ozone and rust. From the ridge, a woman in a gray suit watched through binoculars as the hatch unsealed with a sigh.

They emerged blinking, six of them, carrying themselves with the easy confidence of people who expect a handshake and a medal. Their patches were sun-bleached but readable. Mission Year One. The woman lowered the binoculars and touched her throat mic.

“Control, they’re out,” she said. Her voice was steady because she had practiced this moment in simulation and dream.

The first man down the ramp lifted a hand. He was young, maybe thirty-five, hair cropped close, eyes bright. “Earth Control,” he called. “This is the Peregrine. We’re back. Took longer than planned on the decel burn, but—” He laughed, breathless with relief. “We’re home.”

The woman walked forward, boots crunching on the basin floor. She stopped ten meters away, where protocol had drawn a line. “Welcome back,” she said. “Please remain where you are.”

He squinted at her suit, at the unfamiliar insignia stitched where old flags used to go. “Is this a joke?” he asked. “You folks change uniforms while we were gone?”

She smiled because smiling was kinder than saying the year out loud. “I’m Dr. Mara Ionescu, Temporal Liaison. We’ve been waiting for you.”

The man glanced over his shoulder. The others clustered behind him: a pilot with grease still under her nails, a biologist hugging a sample case, an engineer already craning toward the hull. “Waiting?” he echoed. “We sent the ping at perihelion. You had it.”

“We did,” Mara said. “Two hundred years ago.”

Silence landed like a dropped tool. The wind hissed across the basin. The man’s mouth opened and closed. “That’s not funny,” he said finally. “We were gone eleven weeks. Twelve, if you count the layover.”

The biologist laughed, sharp and brittle. “Did we overshoot a joke holiday?”

Mara tapped her wrist. Her display bloomed, projecting a date that glowed between them. The man stared at it as if it were written in a language he’d never learned. He shook his head. “Our clocks—”

“—are correct,” Mara finished. “For you.”

They took them inside a mobile shelter that hummed with climate control. Water was offered; the crew drank greedily. The pilot’s hands shook as she set her cup down. “We burned hard at the edge of the sun,” she said. “Gravity assist. Relativistic effects were within margin. We ran the math a hundred times.”

“I know,” Mara said. She gestured, and the walls lit with images: archives, cities growing and dissolving, coastlines redrawn by retreating seas. “Time dilation alone doesn’t explain it. We don’t fully understand the rest.”

The engineer stood, restless. “Show us the ship’s telemetry.”

“We have it,” Mara said. “It matches your logs. That’s the problem.”

They argued then, voices overlapping, clinging to checklists like lifelines. The biologist opened her case and spread slides on the table, labels in careful handwriting. “These are fresh,” she insisted. “Cell division rates consistent with weeks. You can test them.”

“We have,” Mara said gently. “They’re fresh.”

“Then what changed?” the pilot demanded. “Us, or Earth?”

Mara hesitated. “Earth didn’t change the way you’re thinking. We did.”

She told them about the long years after the Peregrine’s launch: the warming that outpaced treaties, the migrations, the cities lifted and abandoned, the languages that braided. About the moment someone noticed that clocks on certain trajectories disagreed in ways that equations couldn’t reconcile. About the theory that time was not a river but a fabric with seams, and that near immense gravity and energy, a vessel might slip along a seam instead of across it.

“You fell between stitches,” Mara said. “You traveled weeks. The rest of us kept going.”

The man—Captain Reyes, his patch said—rubbed his face. “My daughter,” he said. “She was six.”

Mara nodded. “She lived a long life. She sent messages, at first. Then she stopped. Her granddaughter is alive. She helped write the protocols I’m following.”

He sat heavily. The pilot swore softly. The engineer stared at his hands as if they might suddenly age in front of him.

Later, Mara walked Reyes to the shelter door. The basin glowed with the low sun, windmills turning on the far ridge like patient insects. “What happens now?” he asked.

“Quarantine. Counseling. You can choose to integrate, if you want. Or we can build you a place together with people like you.”

“Like us,” he said. He looked back at the ship, at the ramp that had carried him down into a future he hadn’t agreed to. “We were gone weeks,” he said again, not as an argument but a fact he was afraid to lose.

Mara met his gaze. “Then hold on to that,” she said. “It’s true.”

That night, as the stars wheeled unfamiliar patterns, the crew lay awake, counting heartbeats, measuring the small, stubborn span of time that belonged to them. Outside, the world continued, vast and patient, making room where it could.

prompt: A translator discovers a word with no direct meaning in any other language. Show the effort to explain it.
story:
The word first appeared in the margin of a shipping ledger from 1893, written in a cramped hand that smelled faintly of camphor when I unfolded the page. It wasn’t listed in the vocabulary compiled by the missionaries, nor in the later glossaries made by the linguists who came with tape recorders and left with grant money. It sat there alone, underlined twice, as if the clerk had hesitated and then decided it was the only thing that would do.

I copied it into my notebook and mouthed it. The sound made a small hollow in the air, like tapping a cup. I wrote three English words beside it, crossed them out, wrote four more, crossed those out too. In the reading room, the fans stirred the dust. Somewhere a cart rattled. The word refused me.

At home that night I tried again. I brewed tea and set the notebook between the mug and the lamp. The word had a shape that suggested something you did with your hands, a making. I wrote: “to arrange.” No. “To prepare.” No. “To steady.” Closer, but still not it. The old clerk had underlined it twice, as if he wanted to catch a thought that was slipping.

The next day I went to see Alma, who had learned the language as a child and forgotten most of it by the time I met her. Her apartment smelled of oranges. She listened while I read the sentence aloud, nodding at the familiar rhythms. When I said the word, she smiled and made a small motion with her fingers, pinching the air.

“It’s like when you put things where they belong,” she said. “But before they belong there.”

“That’s not helpful,” I said, and then apologized.

She laughed. “It’s helpful to me. My mother used it when she was setting the table and when she was telling us to sit still before guests arrived. She used it when my father was sick and she smoothed the sheet. It’s… the making-ready that’s also a promise.”

I wrote that down. “The making-ready that’s also a promise.” It was too long. It wasn’t a definition so much as a trail of breadcrumbs.

Back at my desk, I tried to build a bridge. In the draft translation, I footnoted the word. The footnote grew. I added examples. I added a metaphor about a river held back by hands, about breath gathered before speaking. I crossed out the river. I crossed out the breath. Each image took the word somewhere else, like explaining the taste of salt by pointing at the sea.

In class that week, I asked my students to help me. They were kind in the way of people who still believe words can be solved like equations. We filled the board with possibilities. One student suggested “anticipatory care.” Another offered “preparatory tenderness.” Someone else laughed and said, “Isn’t it just ‘poise’?”

I shook my head. “Poise is a posture. This is an action. And it’s not only about people.” I told them about the ledger, about the clerk underlining twice. “It’s what you do to a thing so that when something else happens, it won’t fall apart.”

They nodded, wrote notes, frowned. The bell rang. The board was erased. The word remained.

A week later, I went back to the archive and asked for more ledgers. I found the word again in a list of supplies sent upriver before the floods. Again in a letter about a marriage, where it appeared between “the gifts” and “the singing.” In a recipe, where it described what you did to the dough after kneading and before baking. Always in the middle, always at the hinge.

I began to think the word wasn’t a thing at all, but a pause that did something. A pause with intention. A pause that held.

At dinner, my partner watched me move the plates. “You’re doing it,” he said.

“Doing what?”

He gestured. I had arranged the table without thinking, spacing the forks just so, setting the water glasses a little farther back. I had smoothed the napkin where it wrinkled. “You’re making room,” he said. “You’re not done yet, but you’re not starting either.”

I sat down slowly. The word hovered between us, unspoken. I tried to say it and failed. I tried to translate my hands and couldn’t.

In the end, the solution was not a word. In the published translation, I left the original in place, italicized. I wrote a note—not a footnote this time, but a paragraph at the beginning of the book. I told the reader what Alma had said, what my students had guessed, what the ledgers showed. I told them the word lived in the moment before arrival, the care taken so arrival wouldn’t bruise.

“This language has a word for that,” I wrote. “We do not. When you see it, imagine the act you perform when you set a chair for someone who has not yet come, trusting they will.”

prompt: A small town votes to rename itself every month. Capture the chaos of the latest change.
story:
The siren went off at noon, the one they used for snow emergencies and boil-water notices and, now, renamings. It wailed once and cut, a reminder more than an alarm. On Main Street, ladders clanged against brick as people scrambled to undo letters before the paint set again. Someone swore. A gull laughed from the roof of the diner.

By the time the votes were tallied, the town had already been three names that morning. Dawn broke on “Good Enough,” the vinyl banner stretched across the municipal building still smelling of ink. At nine, when the absentee ballots came in from the assisted living center, it tipped to “Port of Saints,” and Father Leahy stood on the steps blessing the new sign with a paper cup of tap water. At eleven, the high school’s online poll surged, and the siren announced “Glamour Falls,” which lasted all of forty-seven minutes until the lunch shift at the cannery swamped the server and tipped it to the current winner: “Sourdough.”

Mara stood on a step stool inside the post office, peeling the adhesive vinyl from the nameplate above the PO boxes. Her fingers were tacky, the glue resisting like a memory. “Sour—what?” Mrs. Kline asked from box 112, clutching a stack of mail addressed to Good Enough.

“Sourdough,” Mara said. “It’s spelled with a hyphen sometimes, but council says no hyphens this month. Too hard for the GIS.”

Mrs. Kline sniffed. “I voted for Port of Saints. My Harold would have liked that.”

Mara smiled the smile she’d learned to keep in her cheeks, not her eyes. She had voted for Glamour Falls because it sounded like a place where she might leave and become someone else. She had voted early, before the cannery shift. It hadn’t mattered.

Outside, a pickup truck backfired, and a chorus of horns answered. The hardware store owner, Cal, was hauling out the ladder again. His sign had been “CAL’S HARDWARE — GOOD ENOUGH SINCE 1963” in the morning, then “PORT OF SAINTS SINCE 1963,” and now he stood squinting at the vinyl letters that spelled “SOURDOU—” because the last letter had curled off in the heat. “Does anyone have an extra G?” he yelled.

“I’ve got an H!” someone called from across the street.

“Keep it,” Cal said. “We’re not a church.”

At the diner, Vera slapped menus down with the old name crossed out in Sharpie and the new one written in bubble letters, steam curling from the grill. “Special today is the Sourdough Melt,” she announced to nobody in particular. “It was the Glamour Melt an hour ago, so if you feel disappointed, that’s on you.”

The mayor—temporary, elected for a month at a time, wearing the sash that got passed like a baton—stood on the courthouse steps with a bullhorn and a spreadsheet. “Okay, folks,” he said. “Okay. Remember to update your addresses with your banks. USPS will forward for thirty days, but after that, it’s on you. And if you have a baby born today—congratulations, and please pick a name that can survive being born in Sourdough.”

A woman in labor laughed and then stopped laughing and grabbed her partner’s arm.

Chaos was a sound more than a sight: the whine of printers spitting new letterhead, the thunk of trash as old signs went into the bin, the ding of phones as navigation apps recalculated and recalculated again. A delivery driver paced in the middle of the street, staring at his map. “Is Sourdough near Good Enough?” he asked nobody.

“Depends how hungry you are,” Vera said.

Mara took her lunch break on the steps, sandwich wrapped in wax paper. She watched the kids chalking the new name on the sidewalk, misspelling it on purpose. “Sour Doe.” “Sore Dough.” A boy drew a loaf with legs. She ate and thought of her father, who had loved the ritual. He’d said the town was practicing freedom, like scales on a piano. You play all the notes so you know which ones are yours.

At one-thirty, the problem arrived in the form of a brown envelope stamped URGENT. It was addressed to “Town of Port of Saints,” and inside was a court notice about a boundary dispute that needed a response by five p.m. Mara took it to the mayor, who took it to the clerk, who took it to the attorney, who shook his head. “They’ve named us wrong,” he said. “We’ll have to file an amendment.”

“Can we?” the mayor asked. “What if we change again?”

“Don’t,” the attorney said, as if to a child reaching for a stove.

The siren did not go off, but the air shifted anyway. Someone had put up a sign on the old mill that read “VOTE AGAIN,” and people gathered beneath it, arguing with the heat. A baker from two towns over had driven in with baskets of actual sourdough and was handing out slices, smiling like a provocateur. “You want the name,” he said. “You gotta earn it.”

By four, the chalk had been washed away by a sudden, violent rain. The vinyl peeled. The ladders came down. In the post office, Mrs. Kline returned with a letter addressed to Sourdough, stamped and neat. “It came through,” she said, surprised. “They found us.”

Mara took the letter and slid it into the slot. She thought about the names they’d worn like costumes and how, under all of them, the same cracks in the sidewalk tripped you if you weren’t watching. At five, the attorney filed the amendment under Sourdough, and it went through because someone on the other end was tired and didn’t ask.

At sunset, the siren stayed quiet. The diner windows glowed. Cal finally found a G. The baker packed up his baskets. The mayor took off the sash and folded it.

Mara walked home, passing the sign at the edge of town. Someone had added a smaller plank beneath the big new name, screwed in crooked. It read: SAME PLACE. She touched it as she went by, just to see if it was real.

prompt: A baker's sourdough starter is rumored to be alive. Show the day it runs away.
story:
The rumor began with a wobble.

Every morning at four, Mara unlocked the bakery and greeted the room like a church. Flour dusted the counters in a pale blessing, the ovens hummed low, and on the highest shelf sat the crock of starter, thick and pale, breathing like something asleep. That morning, as she reached for it, the crock shifted an inch to the left.

Mara froze. The shelf was level; she’d checked it last week with a carpenter’s bubble because she trusted nothing. She waited, counting her breaths. The crock stilled. The room smelled of yesterday’s loaves—wheat and sour and heat held over—and something else, a wet apple tang.

“Don’t,” she said, softly, to no one. She lifted the crock. The starter inside had risen high, domed and cratered like a lunar surface. It sighed when she set it down on the counter. A bubble broke with a soft pop.

She fed it. That was the rule: you fed it, you listened, you kept it warm. The rumor said that if you fed it right, it listened back.

Customers talked. They leaned over the glass and whispered that her bread tasted like home even if they’d never been here before. They said the crust sang when you broke it. They said the starter was alive. Mara smiled and nodded and took their money and went back to work.

By six, the ovens roared. The first loaves slid in on peels, and the starter was capped and set back on its shelf. Mara turned to shape dough. She was halfway through when she heard a scrape.

The cap rolled off the shelf and hit the counter with a clack.

Mara looked up. The crock leaned. Slowly, it tipped itself back upright. A smear of starter oozed down the side like a pale tongue, tasting air.

“No,” she said again, louder. “We don’t do that.”

The bakery door chimed. Old Mr. Kline shuffled in, coat buttoned wrong. “Morning,” he said, peering around. “Smells good.”

“Morning,” Mara said, not taking her eyes off the crock.

He followed her gaze. “That the famous one?”

She wiped her hands on her apron. “It’s a mixture of flour and water. And time.”

“Everything’s time,” he said. “You ever think it might want something?”

Mara didn’t answer. The starter pulsed. A bubble rose and burst. The smear crept another inch.

When Mr. Kline left with his rye, the bakery was suddenly too quiet. The starter tipped again, this time further. It thudded onto the counter. The lid skidded and fell to the floor.

Mara moved without thinking. She grabbed a bench scraper and tried to corral the spill. The starter flowed around the metal, warm and alive, sticking to the wood. It had a will, a direction. It slid toward the edge of the counter.

“Stop,” she said, breath coming fast. She tried to scoop it back into the crock. It resisted, clinging, pulling away, leaving threads that snapped back.

She remembered the first day she’d mixed it, years ago, in a borrowed kitchen. How she’d named it for her grandmother, because names made things stay. How she’d carried it through apartments and power outages, fed it by candlelight, whispered to it when the ovens broke. How she’d told it her plans.

The starter reached the edge and spilled, a slow-motion avalanche. It hit the floor with a wet sound and spread, seeking the door.

Mara laughed then, a sharp sound. “You can’t,” she said. “You don’t have legs.”

The starter found the crack under the door. It thinned itself, stretching, becoming something like a tongue of paste that slid and slid. The door trembled. The bell chimed, once, as if someone had brushed past.

Mara ran. She flung the door open. Outside, the morning had sharpened. The street was damp from last night’s rain. The starter flowed across the threshold and down the step, leaving a pale trail. It paused, as if tasting the world. A pigeon hopped closer, cocked its head. The starter swelled, bubbled, and rolled away from the bird, down the sidewalk.

“Wait,” Mara said. She stepped after it, apron flapping. The starter moved faster now, thickening and thinning to fit the cracks, rolling over cigarette butts and grit, gathering crumbs. It left a scent behind—sour and sweet and wild.

A woman with a stroller stopped. “Is that—”

“Bread,” Mara said, helpless. “Kind of.”

The starter reached the corner where the city sewer breathed out warm damp air. It hesitated. Mara knelt, palms on the concrete. She could feel the heat through her jeans.

“I kept you alive,” she said. “I need you.”

The starter pulsed. A bubble rose, big as a fist, and burst, spattering her hands. It felt like a kiss. Then it slid into the grate, down into the dark where water moved and food drifted and time did what it always did.

The street was suddenly just a street. Mara sat back on her heels. Her hands smelled right.

Back in the bakery, the ovens were ready. Dough waited. The shelf was empty. Mara washed her hands and set to work. The loaves rose anyway, slower, different. When they baked, the crust did not sing so loud, but it crackled, a quieter music.

By noon, people came and bought bread. They said it tasted good. Mara nodded and smiled and felt something loosen in her chest.

That evening, she closed up and swept the floor. In the quiet, she heard the city breathing. Somewhere below, something fed and fed. Mara took a clean jar and measured flour and water. She stirred. She waited.

prompt: A fisherman finds a phone in a fish's stomach. The last message changes his life.
story:
The fish came up wrong, heavy in a way that made the line hum instead of sing. Mateo leaned back, boots digging into the skiff’s wet boards, and hauled until the net kissed the surface. It was a halibut, broad as a door, pale eye rolling. He clubbed it quick, murmured an apology like his father had taught him, and slid it into the tub with the others. The fog lay low over the inlet, and the diesel throbbed like a tired heart.

He cleaned his catch at the dock because the gulls were less bold there. When he slit the halibut’s belly, something hard clinked against the knife. Not bone. Not a hook. He reached in and drew out a rectangle wrapped in kelp and a spiderweb of fishing line. A phone. The glass was spidered but intact, salt crusted around the seams. Mateo stood with it dripping in his palm, the halibut’s blood seeping into the grooves of the dock.

He laughed once, a short bark, and shook his head. The sea ate everything. He had found license plates, shoes, a plastic dinosaur once. A phone felt like a punchline. He pocketed it and finished his work. The fog lifted a little, showing the mountains like blunt teeth.

At home he rinsed the phone in fresh water and left it on the windowsill, as if that might dry the ocean out of it. He lived alone in a cedar-shingled house with a view of the harbor and a calendar from the co-op frozen on April. His wife, Lucía, had left in February, a suitcase thumping down the steps before dawn, the ferry horn answering like a dare. “I can’t keep waiting for you to come back from the water,” she’d said. “Even when you’re here, you’re not.”

That night, the phone buzzed.

Mateo stared at it like it might be a fish again, alive and offended. The screen glowed, then dimmed, then glowed. He touched it with the tip of his finger. It woke, stubborn as a barnacle, and showed a lock screen photo of a woman squinting into sun, hair blown sideways, a toddler perched on her hip. A notification banner slid down.

— Please, if anyone finds this —

The rest cut off. Mateo’s heart did a small, foolish leap. He tapped, and the phone opened without a code, as if trusting him by accident. Messages loaded slowly, a tide creeping up the beach. The last one was dated three days ago, sent but undelivered.

Please, if anyone finds this, my name is Eliza. I dropped my phone off the south jetty. My son was with me. He’s two. He ran toward the water and I went after him and I think I lost it then. If you can read this, please call my sister. Her number is in my contacts. Or call the Coast Guard. Or just come to the lighthouse and tell them I’m okay. Please.

Mateo read it twice, then again. The room felt smaller, the walls leaning in like the sides of a boat in a swell. He scrolled. Earlier messages were ordinary—groceries, a missed call, a photo of a crab trap with a caption about luck. There was a draft that had never been sent: If something happens, tell—

He swallowed. He checked the battery. Twelve percent. The signal bars flickered, found nothing. He stepped onto the porch and raised the phone like an offering. The harbor lay quiet, boats at their moorings, a ferry sliding past like a thought you didn’t want to finish.

The lighthouse sat on a spit of rock two miles from town, reachable by a road that narrowed and narrowed until it felt like it might end in air. Mateo hadn’t been out there in years. He used to take Lucía, back when the climb felt like a promise instead of a chore. He grabbed his jacket, the phone, and his keys.

The lighthouse was open. A volunteer in a knit cap was making tea behind the desk. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost,” she said.

Mateo set the phone down gently, as if it might spook. “I found this in a fish,” he said, which sounded insane even to him. “There’s a message.”

She read it, her mouth tightening. “We had a call,” she said. “About a woman and a child near the jetty. They were okay. Scared, cold. The phone was gone, though. We thought the tide took it.”

“Did you—” He stopped, because the question was selfish.

“We got them to the clinic,” she said. “Her sister picked them up.”

Relief came like a wave, knocking his knees soft. He hadn’t realized how hard he was bracing.

“Can I charge it?” he asked.

They plugged it in behind the desk. The battery crept up. The volunteer found the sister’s number and dialed. Mateo listened to the ringing, the click, a voice thick with sleep and gratitude and something like laughter breaking through tears. “Eliza?” the sister said, and then, “Someone found your phone. In a fish, apparently.”

Eliza came on the line. She laughed too, a startled sound. “That tracks,” she said. “Everything’s been weird.”

“I’m Mateo,” he said. “I fish the inlet. I’m glad you’re okay.”

“Me too,” she said, and then there was a pause, the space where thank-yous get inadequate. “If you ever want a free coffee, my sister owns the café by the ferry.”

After, he stood on the lighthouse steps and watched the water slap the rocks. He thought of the halibut, its pale eye rolling, and of how the sea didn’t care what it swallowed, only what it returned.

He went home and pulled Lucía’s number from the back of a drawer where he’d tucked it like a charm. His hand shook, then steadied. When she answered, her voice was wary, then warm.

“I found something today,” he said. “It made me think about how easy it is to lose things. And how sometimes they come back wrong, but still useful.”

There was a long silence. In it, he imagined the road to the lighthouse, narrowing and narrowing, but not ending.

prompt: A journalist receives anonymous letters that predict minor disasters. They must decide whether to publish.
story:
The first letter arrived on a Tuesday that smelled like burnt coffee and printer toner. It was addressed to the newsroom in careful block letters, no return address, a Forever stamp placed slightly crooked. Mara Lin, metro reporter, slit it open with her key.

At 11:42 a.m. tomorrow, the westbound Green Line will stop between Oak and Madison for fourteen minutes due to a signal fault. No injuries. Delays will ripple until 1:05 p.m.

Mara snorted. The Green Line stopped all the time. Fourteen minutes was oddly precise, but it was also a nothingburger. She read it again, then tossed it into her desk drawer, beneath a fossilized granola bar and a stack of sticky notes.

The next day, she was on her way to an interview when the train lurched and the lights flickered. A voice crackled overhead, apologetic, mechanical. She checked her watch: 11:42. She timed it because the letter had stuck to her brain like a burr. Fourteen minutes later, they were moving again. The platform at Madison was crowded with people shaking their phones like talismans.

Back at the newsroom, she dug the letter out. She didn’t tell anyone. Coincidence, she told herself. People predicted things all the time. Broken clocks.

The second letter came on Friday, thicker paper, same handwriting. At approximately 6:20 p.m. on Saturday, the fountain in Daley Plaza will fail and spray water onto the west walkway. Two people will slip. One will bruise an elbow. No lawsuits.

Mara stood at the window with it, watching pigeons argue over a French fry. She thought of her mother, who had once said, You’re not special just because you noticed something after it happened. That night she dreamed of water bursting from stone mouths.

Saturday evening, she found herself at Daley Plaza, pretending she was waiting for a friend. At 6:18 p.m., a man in a Cubs cap stepped onto the slick, then a woman with a stroller. The fountain coughed, surged, and water arced where it shouldn’t. The man flailed, the woman grabbed the stroller, a teenager laughed and slipped, then swore. The man rubbed his elbow, wincing. A city worker shut a valve. People dispersed.

Mara’s phone buzzed with a text from her editor, Jonah: You alive? Deadline moved. She typed back a thumbs-up she didn’t feel.

The third letter arrived Monday morning. This one smelled faintly of smoke, as if it had been near a stove. At 9:10 p.m. tonight, a transformer will blow behind the Crescent Theater. Power out for twelve minutes. The film will pause. People will clap when it comes back.

Mara went to Jonah’s office and closed the door. Jonah was forty with a beard he trimmed when he remembered. He had a way of leaning back as if bracing for weather.

“I think someone is sending me predictions,” she said. “They’ve been right.”

He smiled the tired smile reserved for psychics and tips from a guy’s cousin. “Define right.”

She told him. He didn’t interrupt. When she finished, he rubbed his face. “Okay,” he said. “Okay. Could be someone with access. Transit worker. Parks maintenance. Utility schedule.”

“Then why anonymous? And why me?”

Jonah shrugged. “You cover the city. You answer your mail.”

“Should we publish?” she asked. The words surprised her by coming out steady.

“Publish what? A pattern? You have three data points. One’s transit, one’s a fountain, one’s not even happened yet.” He leaned forward. “Look, if you run this and you’re wrong even once, we look like we’re laundering nonsense. If you’re right, people panic over every hiccup. Minor disasters aren’t a public service. They’re a stress test.”

That night, Mara sat in the Crescent Theater with a tub of popcorn she didn’t want. The movie reached a quiet scene. At 9:10, the screen went black. Someone groaned. Someone clapped. When the power returned, applause rippled, embarrassed and relieved.

Mara didn’t clap.

The fourth letter came with no stamp, as if it had been hand-delivered. Tomorrow at 3:05 p.m., a sinkhole will open on Birch Street. No cars will fall in. A dog will bark for a long time.

Mara drove to Birch Street early. It was a modest block with brick bungalows and a woman watering petunias. At 3:04, a delivery truck rolled by. At 3:05, the asphalt sagged like a breath leaving a body. A hole opened. A golden retriever went berserk.

She filmed it on her phone, hands shaking. This wasn’t a schedule. This was something else.

Back at her desk, she wrote two drafts. One was cautious, hedged, framed as a mystery tipster with an improbable run of luck.
