She stacks the sacks in a metal bin the café next door uses for ash and sets kindling beneath. Her hands shake as she strikes the match. The flour goes up with a whoomph, a pale cloud blooming, then fire licking, greedy. She steps back, heart pounding.

A figure stands at the mouth of the alley.

It’s her, older by a decade, hair shot through with gray, eyes deeper-set, face carved by lines she recognizes from her mother. She smells of smoke and bread. “You burned it,” the woman says, and lets out a breath like she’s been holding it for years.

Mara swallows. “You wrote me.”

“Yes.” The older Mara steps closer, careful of the heat. “I didn’t, the first time. I thought I knew better. I always do.”

“What was it?” Mara asks. “The flour?”

“A contaminant,” the older one says. “Not poison exactly. A fungus that produces something nasty when heated. The mill changed suppliers. I didn’t ask enough questions.” She looks at the fire. “People got sick. One died. It ruined us. Ruined me.”

The fire crackles. Flour ash floats like snow.

“How are you here?” Mara asks.

The older woman smiles without humor. “I learned to listen. And to write. And to accept that sometimes you have to be the warning.”

They stand together until the flames die down to embers. The older Mara fades, or maybe she was never solid to begin with, just a certainty made flesh. “Trust yourself,” she says, and then she’s gone.

That night, Mara scrubs the bakery until her arms ache. She throws away everything that touched the flour. She calls the mill again and again until someone answers, and she says words like contamination and liability and report. She does not sleep.

In the morning, she opens late with bread made from the last of her old stock. People come back cautiously. Mr. Keane nods. The child smiles. Life knits itself back together, uneven but holding.

Weeks later, a new letter appears, this one written in a steadier hand than she remembers ever having. It says only: Thank you for trusting me. —M

Mara smiles, tucks it into the recipe box, and gets back to work.

prompt: A mapmaker is asked to chart a city that changes street names daily. Show their method.
story:
The first morning I arrive with a compass and a notebook, the street outside my lodging is called Alder Mercy. By noon it is called Coppershade. By dusk, a boy chalks over the plaque and writes Laughter’s End, misspelling the apostrophe and grinning at me as if we share a secret.

I am not here to chase names. That is the first rule I write down. Names are weather. They pass.

The city hired me because their old maps failed. Deliverymen got lost. Ambulances arrived late. Tourists cried. The mayor shook my hand and said, “Chart us as we are.” I asked him what that meant. He said, “You’re the mapmaker.”

So I watch.

On the second day, I learn the cadence. Names change at dawn and dusk, but also at weddings, at funerals, when a shop closes, when a rumor takes hold. There is no committee. The names come from mouths. When enough mouths agree, the plaques change. The city employs a small army of metalworkers who wait in alcoves with ladders and drills, listening. When a name tips, they move.

I stand on a corner where three streets meet. I do not write their names. I sketch the angle of sunlight, the way the bakery’s warmth spills into the cold, the echo between brick and glass. I mark the corner with a triangle and a note: bread smell mornings; violin afternoons; shouting nights. The method is not secret, but it is particular. I map invariants.

On the third day, a woman named Inez takes me for coffee and asks if I am failing on purpose. “You haven’t written anything down,” she says, peering at my notebook.

I show her the page. There are dots, arrows, smudges where rain has run ink into rivers. There are little symbols: a spiral for gossip, a square for law, a dot with a tail for hunger. “The streets are bones,” I say. “The names are skin.”

She laughs and tells me her address, which I cannot write because it will not be true when she leaves the café. Instead I ask her how long it takes her to walk home. “Nine minutes,” she says. I write that.

Time is steadier than names. Sound is steadier. The distance between the church bell and the riverbank does not care what it is called.

I begin to walk with a metronome. It ticks at a pace that fits my legs. I count steps between fixed things: the statue of the general with the chipped nose, the fig tree that splits the sidewalk, the alley that smells of soap. I do not measure meters. I measure effort. A hill is not tall; it is a breath.

At dusk, a procession passes me. Someone has died. The street becomes Sorrow Way as the coffin crosses it, and the metalworkers appear as if summoned by the tolling bell. I stop my counting and stand aside. When they pass, the street sloughs off the name like a coat. It becomes Back Way again, because someone says it.

On the fourth day, a man in a blue jacket stops me. “You’re the one making the map,” he says. It is not a question. “My shop can’t be found anymore.”

“What do you sell?” I ask.

“Buttons,” he says. He opens a tin. They gleam like coins. He shows me one carved with a bird.

I follow him. His shop is halfway down a lane that used to be called Needle Row. Now the plaque says Promise Slip. The lane bends. I draw the bend. I draw the way the light dims after the bend. I draw the sound of his door: a bell with a cracked note. “People find you by the sound,” I tell him. He looks offended. Then he listens. The bell rings. He nods.

By the sixth day, I have learned the city’s grammar. Markets are nouns; bridges are verbs; dead ends are secrets. I color the bridges red and write what they do: carry, delay, conceal. I do not label the river. I draw its width at flood and at drought. I note the taste of it at three points. Bitter, sweet, iron.

The mayor asks for a progress report. I bring him a sheet covered in shapes and words that are not names. He frowns. “How will anyone use this?”

I take him to Alder Mercy, which is now called Laughter’s End again. A cart blocks the way. A crowd gathers. I point to my map. “There is another route,” I say, and I lead him through a passage marked only by a spiral. We arrive behind the bakery, where the warmth spills. He breathes. “How did you know?”

“Because gossip flows faster than carts,” I say. “And warmth draws feet.”

On the last day, I compile. I overlay my pages. The city emerges, not as a list of names but as a net of habits. Where people pause. Where they hurry. Where they sing. I add one thing at the end: a blank margin. “For weather,” I write.

When I leave, the street outside my lodging has no plaque at all. The metalworkers are resting. A boy chalks nothing. I walk nine minutes to the café where Inez sits. She asks if the map is finished.

“It will never be finished,” I say. I show her the page with the triangle corner. “But it will always work.”

She folds it once and puts it in her pocket. Outside, the city changes its skin. The bones hold.

prompt: A market sells memories in jars. Describe a customer buying their own.
story:
The market opened at dawn, when the air was still cool enough to make the glass sweat. Stalls unfurled awnings like wings. Bells chimed softly as jars were set out on felt: cloudy ones, bright ones, jars with corks wrapped in twine, jars with lids stamped in brass. Each held a memory. You could tell by the way the light behaved inside them, bending as if it were water.

Mara came late, after the rush of people who bought nostalgia before breakfast. She paused at the edge, listening. The market had a sound like a distant shore—murmurs, the clink of glass, a laugh that ended too soon. A man hawked his wares with a voice trained to soothe. A woman argued over price, her hands fluttering like birds.

Mara had not planned to come. She had not even planned to be curious. But the thought had been knocking at her for weeks, ever since she found the empty space in her chest where something used to be and could not name it.

She stopped at a stall with a blue tablecloth, frayed at the corners. The vendor was old in the way that suggested patience rather than years. He wore a cardigan despite the warmth and had the careful hands of someone who knew how easily things could be broken.

“What are you looking for?” he asked, not looking at her but at the jars, as if they might speak first.

“I’m not sure,” Mara said. She kept her hands in her pockets. “I was told you could help me find something.”

He smiled. “We can try.”

The jars were labeled in a neat hand: First Kiss, Last Argument, The Day It Snowed in June. Some had names; some had only dates. One jar near the center caught her eye. It was small and unassuming, with a strip of paper tied around its neck. On the paper was written her name.

Her breath went shallow. “That one,” she said. “How did—”

The vendor glanced at the label. “Ah,” he said. “Yes. That happens.”

“What happens?”

“People come back for themselves.”

She touched the jar. It was warm. Inside, the light was amber, slow-moving, like honey. When she lifted it, the weight surprised her. Heavier than it looked.

“How much?” she asked.

“For that?” He considered her. “It depends.”

“On what?”

“On whether you want it.”

“I do.”

He shook his head gently. “That’s not the same.”

Mara set the jar down. “I don’t understand.”

He leaned closer. “Memories are not souvenirs. Buying your own is… complicated.”

“I don’t care,” she said. “I want it back.”

He sighed. “What do you think it is?”

She swallowed. “I think it’s the summer I was sixteen.”

His eyebrows rose. “Specific.”

“I think it’s the day my mother taught me how to swim.” The words came out before she could stop them. Her throat tightened. “I think it’s the last time she held my hand without thinking about it.”

The vendor was quiet for a moment. Around them, the market hummed. A jar shattered somewhere; there was a gasp, then laughter, then a hush as the memory leaked out in a silver mist and vanished.

“You’ve lost memories before,” he said.

“Yes.”

“You sold them?”

“No. I lost them.” She pressed her palm to her chest. “After the accident, there were holes. The doctors said it was normal. That the brain protects itself.”

“Protection,” he murmured, “is another word for forgetting.”

She bristled. “Are you going to sell it to me or not?”

He reached under the table and brought out a small scale. “Payment isn’t always money.”

She glanced at the jars around them. “I can pay.”

He shook his head. “For your own memory, the price is exchange.”

“Exchange what?”

“Another memory.”

Her mouth went dry. “Which one?”

“That,” he said, “is up to you.”

Mara closed her eyes. Images flickered behind her lids: the smell of cut grass; the taste of oranges; a face she loved and lost and loved again. She opened her eyes. “If I give you one, will I ever get it back?”

He met her gaze. “No.”

“And if I don’t buy this, will it stay here?”

“For a while.”

“And then?”

He shrugged. “Memories don’t like to sit still.”

She looked at the jar with her name. The light inside pulsed, as if aware of her attention. She imagined opening it, letting the amber spill into her, filling the hollow places. She imagined the weight lifting.

“What if I change?” she asked. “What if the memory changes me?”

“It will,” he said simply.

She laughed once, sharp. “Everything does.”

She took a breath. “All right.”

“What will you give?”

She reached into herself, feeling for something she could bear to lose. Her fingers closed around a moment she had carried like a talisman: a rainy afternoon in a café, steam fogging the windows, a stranger’s smile across a chipped mug. It had been small, but it had taught her something about kindness. She hesitated.

“Another,” she said, surprising herself. “I’ll give you my fear of water.”

He looked at her, startled. “That’s not a memory.”

“It started as one,” she said. “The accident. The cold. The dark. It’s followed me ever since. Take that.”

He studied her, then nodded. He took an empty jar and held it out. “Close your eyes.”

She did. She felt a tug, gentle but insistent, like a tide. Something loosened in her chest. She gasped as the fear slid out of her, a cold thread unraveling. When she opened her eyes, the empty jar held a pale blue swirl, trembling.

He corked it. “Done.”

He slid her jar toward her. “Open it when you’re ready.”

She paid him with shaking hands, then stepped away from the stall, clutching the jar to her chest. She found a quiet corner by the fountain, sat on the stone edge, and uncorked it.

The amber light rose, warm and familiar. It seeped into her skin, into her breath. She smelled chlorine and sunscreen. She heard laughter, felt a hand steadying her elbow. She was sixteen, and the water was bright, and her mother’s voice was patient.

Mara laughed and cried at once. When it was done, the jar was empty.

She stood, heart pounding. The market looked the same, and yet not. She walked toward the fountain. Without thinking, she took off her shoes and stepped into the water.

It was cold. It was clear. It did not frighten her.

She waded in, smiling, and did not look back.

prompt: A violinist can make anyone cry, including themselves. Describe the first time they use it on purpose.
story:
The first time it happened by accident, I was thirteen and practicing in the laundry room because the walls were concrete and my mother said the neighbors would forgive us more easily if the sound didn’t float. I was working through a simple étude when the dryer thumped to a stop and I heard my mother sit down on the stairs. She didn’t say anything. She just stayed there until I finished and then she cried into her hands like she had forgotten how to stop. Later she told me she’d been thinking about my father, gone three months by then, and I believed her. For years after, I believed it.

The second time, it was my teacher, a woman with ironed scarves and a face like a patient clock. She wiped her eyes, laughed it off, said she’d had a long day. “You’re very expressive,” she said, which was the word everyone used because they didn’t have another.

I learned to play around it. I learned how to aim my bow where the sound stayed bright, how to keep the phrases lifted, how to end before anyone could sink. But the thing didn’t leave. It waited, coiled in certain intervals, in the grain of the wood where my chin had polished it smooth.

The first time I used it on purpose, it was raining so hard the gutters overflowed and the city smelled like coins. I was playing in the subway, which I hadn’t done before, not really. I needed the money. Rent was due, and the orchestra had cut two concerts that month, and my sister’s texts were growing shorter and more careful, like she was afraid of tripping something in me. I set my case down on the wet tile and the hinge squealed, and I felt the weight of the violin in my hand, familiar as my own wrist.

People hurried past. The rain followed them underground, dripping from coats, from hair, from the ends of umbrellas. A man stopped to adjust his shoe. A woman pressed her phone to her ear and said, “No, I can’t talk now.” The platform filled and emptied and filled again. I played a fast thing at first, something that bounced, and the sound scattered like sparrows. Coins chimed. It was enough to keep going, but it wasn’t enough to stop the panic fluttering in my chest.

Then I saw him.

He was sitting on the bench with his hands folded, not looking at anything. He wore a jacket that had once been navy and now was the color of old bruises. His shoes were soaked. There was a bandage on his forehead, the cheap kind, already peeling at the edges. He looked like someone who had been waiting for a long time and hadn’t been told what for.

I don’t know why I chose him. Or maybe I do. Maybe it was because he wasn’t looking, because he didn’t feel like an audience yet. I lifted the violin and felt the familiar ache settle into my shoulder, and I let my bow drop into the place I had been avoiding for years.

It started low. It always does. The sound gathered itself like a breath held too long. I felt it slide along the wood and into my jaw, and then it went out into the station and found him.

He flinched, like someone had said his name. He looked up, and his eyes were bright and unfocused, like glass in rain. I played slowly, pulling the notes until they thinned and then thickened again. I let the melody remember things. I let it forget them. The station quieted, not because people stopped talking but because their voices didn’t matter anymore.

My hands shook. The bow felt heavier with each stroke. The sound turned back on me, the way it always did when I let it go this far. My throat closed. I saw my father’s shoes by the door, the way he lined them up even when he was late. I saw my sister asleep on the couch with her textbooks open, the dog-eared pages. I tasted the metal of the rain.

The man on the bench put his face in his hands and cried without trying to hide it. The woman with the phone lowered it. The man with the shoe sat down. I felt it take them, one by one, like a tide finding the lowest places. I felt it take me. Tears slid off my chin and spotted the violin, darkening the varnish. I kept playing.

When it ended, it didn’t stop so much as release. The sound loosened its grip and the station breathed again. Someone clapped once, uncertain. Coins rained into the case. A bill folded itself into the corner.

The man stood up. He came close, close enough that I could smell the soap on his hands. “Thank you,” he said, and his voice was hoarse but steady. “I needed that.”

I nodded because if I spoke I would start again. He left, and the crowd followed, and the rain kept coming down the stairs. I wiped my face on my sleeve and put the violin back under my chin.

I didn’t play that way again that day. I packed up and went home and counted the money and paid the rent. That night, alone in my room, I took the violin out once more and held it without playing. My hands were still damp.

I understood then what I had done. Not just that I could make people cry, but that I could choose it. That the sound was a door and I had learned how to open it.

I set the violin back in its case and closed the lid carefully, the hinge quiet this time. The rain stopped sometime before morning.

prompt: A lighthouse beam starts spelling Morse code. Decide who is reading it.
story:
The beam came around every seven seconds, white as a blade, cutting the fog into slices. Most nights it was just a rhythm you learned to live inside of, like breathing. Tonight it stuttered.

I was on the catwalk of Turpin Light, thirty feet above the black water, scraping guano from the railing with a putty knife because the maintenance schedule said Wednesday and Wednesday meant birds. The foghorn had gone silent an hour before—electrical fault we’d flagged last week—and the quiet made the light louder somehow. When the beam hesitated, I felt it before I saw it, a hitch in the turn.

Long flash. Short. Short. Long.

I stopped scraping. The knife clinked against the railing and fell, ringing once before vanishing into the dark. The beam came again. Long. Short. Short. Long.

My father taught me Morse with a flashlight and the kitchen door. He’d click the beam through the frosted glass while I sat on the other side counting seconds out loud. He said you learned it in your body first. You learned the way a dash felt heavier than a dot, the way letters had a gait. He died ten years ago and I still sometimes catch myself tapping patterns on the steering wheel.

Long short short long. That was C.

The beam paused, then flashed again, quicker now. Short short short. S. It kept going. Short. E.

C S E.

I swallowed. The fog curled and uncurl like breath around the lantern room. The light finished its arc and went dark behind the tower. Seven seconds. When it returned it did it again, the same letters, the same pacing. CSE.

There was no one else on the rock. The island had a dock and a weather shed and this tower, and the gulls and me. The mainland was three miles away, a smudge of sodium lights and radio towers. Ships used GPS now. No one needed this light, not really. It was a museum piece kept burning out of habit and the stubbornness of men who loved lenses.

I ran inside, boots ringing on iron, and climbed the spiral to the lantern room. The Fresnel lens floated in its bath of mercury, a cathedral of glass rotating on a motor older than my father. The shutter assembly was bolted open. No shutters meant no Morse. Except someone had rigged a hand brake—an old manual override I’d never seen used—to the rotation. I grabbed the rail as the beam came around and felt the tremor through the metal when it slowed.

“Hello?” My voice vanished into the glass.

The beam blinked. Short short short. S.

I counted under my breath. Long long long. O.

S O S.

My chest tightened. I yanked the radio from the wall and keyed it, calling the Coast Guard, my words tumbling. “Turpin Light, automated distress signal—no, visual—SOS from the lantern room, repeat—”

Static. The storm that had rolled through earlier had taken the repeater offline. I slapped the radio and laughed, a sharp sound that made me angry. Of course.

The beam changed. It spelled again, faster now, the pauses clean. I forced myself to breathe and read.

L O O K.

A finger of cold slid down my spine. Look where?

The beam swept past the windows and across the water. I followed it to the southwest, where the fog thinned. Something darker than the dark moved there, low and wrong. I grabbed the binoculars and leaned out, bracing myself.

A boat. Small. Too small. An inflatable, half-collapsed, wallowing. There were shapes in it, huddled shapes, and when the beam hit them they flinched and raised their hands, not in greeting but to shield their eyes. The motor hung dead in the water.

The light spelled again.

T H E Y.

A pause. A longer pause.

C A N T.

The apostrophe wasn’t in Morse, but the missing letter was loud as a shout.

The beam stuttered as I wrestled the brake, trying to keep the light on them longer, to give them something to hold onto. I thought of my father, of how he used to say the light was a promise you made to people you would never meet.

I ran back down the stairs and out onto the catwalk, waving my arms uselessly, then ran again to the radio. I climbed the tower to get line-of-sight, yelling into the handset, repeating coordinates until my voice went hoarse and the static shifted, just a little, into a voice that said, “Say again?”

When I looked back, the beam had stopped spelling. It turned smooth and steady, the old rhythm restored. On the water, the dark shape was still there, now brighter as a cutter’s searchlight cut through the fog from the east.

Later, when it was quiet again and the gulls had resettled, I stood in the lantern room and put my hand on the rail. The brake was warm.

I don’t know who had the idea to teach the light to speak tonight. Maybe it was me, without knowing it, counting seconds and patterns the way I always have. Maybe it was the tower itself, remembering an older language.

I do know who read it. I did. And because I did, a promise held.

prompt: A public fountain starts running with black ink. The town reacts in unexpected ways.
story:
On a Tuesday that smelled like rain though the sky was bright, the fountain in Market Square began to run with black ink.

At first it was just a ribbon in the basin, a dark vein threading the usual blue. Mrs. Ionescu, who sold cherries from a cart nearby, noticed when a drop splashed onto her wrist and stained the thin hairs there. She licked it, out of habit, and made a face. “Bitter,” she said, and flicked her hand. The fountain’s cherub—once white, now gray with pigeon history—kept pouring, its stone mouth serene as the water thickened and darkened.

By nine o’clock the basin was a mirror of night. The sound changed too, from the bright hiss of water to a softer, heavier slop, as if the square had grown a pulse.

The town did not panic. Not at first. The postman leaned his bike and dipped a finger, writing his initials on the stone rim. They shone for a moment and then blurred. Two teenagers took selfies, their faces reflected like ghosts. A woman from the council arrived with a clipboard and frowned at it, as if the ink were a scheduling conflict. She called the water department, then her sister, then the mayor’s assistant, and took notes that smeared.

The artists came before the officials. A woman with a scarf like a banner brought brushes and a stack of paper, kneeling to catch the ink as it spilled. She laughed when it soaked through. “It’s too alive,” she said, as if the fountain were an animal refusing to be milked. Children trailed fingers through the basin and drew mustaches on each other, hands blackened, eyes bright. A boy tried to wash his hands in the sink at the café and watched the water there run clear, obedient. He went back to the square, offended on the fountain’s behalf.

By noon, rumors had settled like flies. It was a protest, said one man, tapping ash into the ink and watching it vanish. It was a punishment, said another, thinking of the old stories where wells went bad when promises were broken. The priest came out in his collar and dipped his rosary, then held it up, beads dripping. “Ink records,” he said to no one in particular. “It remembers.”

The laundromat owner, whose windows looked onto the square, saw an opportunity. He dragged out a rack of white shirts and let the ink splatter them. “Limited edition,” he told a woman who had come to complain about her children. She laughed and bought one.

The mayor finally arrived with a megaphone and a face practiced for emergencies. He told people to keep back. He told them not to drink it. He told them the town would get to the bottom of it. Someone shouted, “We already did!” and held up a bucket, sloshing.

When the fire brigade tried to shut the fountain off, the valve refused. The men’s gloves came away black, the ink seeping into the cracks of their skin, mapping the whorls of their fingerprints. One of them, a quiet man named Pavel, stared at his hands as if they were suddenly legible. “It’s like the old school ink,” he said softly. “It stains if you don’t wash fast enough.”

As afternoon wore on, the square became a writing desk. People brought ledgers, envelopes, walls. A baker wrote the names of his dead parents on the stone where he used to sit and smoke. The letters bled and held. A girl wrote a confession on her thigh and then scrubbed at it, crying when it wouldn’t come off, then laughing when her friends circled her with their own secrets.

There were refusals too. Mrs. Ionescu covered her cherries with cloth and turned her cart away from the square. “I’ve sold enough stains,” she said, though she kept glancing back. The councilwoman’s notes had become a black page. She tore it out and started again on her palm.

At dusk, the ink thinned. It went from night to bruise to gray. People leaned in, disappointed. The artists packed up. The mayor wiped his mouth. The fountain coughed, once, and ran clear.

The square smelled like iron and paper. Hands were ruined. Shoes were ruined. The cherub’s mouth was clean.

In the days that followed, the town found itself altered. The shirts from the laundromat sold out. The baker’s stone held the names until winter, when frost cracked them into illegible lines. Children traced their old drawings in chalk and found the chalk slid away from certain grooves, as if the ink had etched the stone. The priest preached about record-keeping and mercy and was surprised by how many people came.

The water department reported nothing wrong. The pipes were old but not that old. The mayor proposed a plaque. No one agreed on the words.

On Friday, Mrs. Ionescu returned to the square with her cherries uncovered. She washed her hands in the fountain and watched the water run clear over the faint shadows that would never quite fade from her skin. She tasted it again, carefully. “Still bitter,” she said, and smiled, because now she knew where to put it.

prompt: A painter finds a hidden door behind a mural they finished years ago. They open it.
story:
The ladder groaned the way it always had, a tired animal complaining as Mara shifted her weight. She hadn’t climbed it in years. The rungs smelled of dust and old varnish. Below her, the municipal library’s rotunda breathed softly—pages turning, a cough, the muted shuffle of shoes. Above her, the mural curved along the dome, its blues dulled by time, its gold leaf tarnished into something like honey.

She had painted it twenty-three years ago, newly returned from Florence, hands steady then, eyes hungry. The city had commissioned a procession of figures: scholars, children, river gods, an allegory of learning threading them all together. She remembered the long afternoons, the radio perched on the scaffolding, the way her wrist ached at night. She remembered finishing and feeling, briefly, complete.

They’d called her back now because a crack had appeared. A hairline fracture ran through the painted sky above the river god’s shoulder. A conservator had suggested stabilization; Mara insisted on seeing it herself. She brought her own brushes, her own small knife, the way some people bring talismans.

Up close, the crack was stranger than she’d expected. It wasn’t a simple fissure in plaster. It outlined a rectangle, subtle as a breath on glass. She traced it with her fingertip. The paint flaked in a way that felt intentional, as if she had once known this shape and then taught herself to forget it.

Her heart knocked. She laughed quietly at herself. Age did that—made ghosts out of drafts and shadows. Still, she fetched the knife and slid the blade gently along the line. A whisper of dust fell. The rectangle loosened.

The panel shifted inward with a sound like a held sigh released.

Mara froze. The ladder creaked. She steadied herself, palm flat against the mural. She had no memory of painting a door. She had no memory of hiding anything.

She pushed. The panel opened just wide enough to reveal darkness and the smell of old oil and damp stone. A hinge glinted, hand-forged, blackened. The door was real.

She looked down. A librarian was stamping returns, oblivious. Mara’s hands trembled. She widened the opening and, with a clumsy swing, stepped through.

The door closed behind her with a soft, final click.

Inside, the air was cool. A narrow stair spiraled down, carved from the thickness of the wall. She descended, one hand on the stone, the other trailing along the curve, counting steps to keep from thinking. Twenty-three steps. Of course.

At the bottom was a room no larger than a walk-in closet. A single bulb hung from a cord, already lit, swaying slightly as if she’d disturbed it. The walls were whitewashed. On a trestle table sat a canvas, face turned toward her. Beside it: her old palette, the wood worn smooth by her thumb, the exact arrangement of colors she favored back then—ultramarine, ochre, vermilion. A radio, silent. A chair with a cardigan draped over the back.

She stepped closer. The canvas depicted a woman on a ladder, painting a dome. The brushstroke at the edge of the sky was unfinished.

Mara’s mouth went dry. She recognized the woman’s hair pinned up with the same tortoiseshell comb she’d lost in Florence. She recognized the mole on her own wrist, the small scar near her thumb. The painting was hers, but not from memory. It was from a moment she had never allowed herself to finish.

On the table lay a folded note. Her handwriting, younger and bolder.

You couldn’t leave it all up there, it read. You needed somewhere to put the rest.

She sat heavily in the chair. The bulb hummed. She remembered now: the night she’d stayed after the others had gone, the way the dome had felt like a sky she could enter. The argument she’d had with Elias that morning, the letter from her mother unopened in her bag. The choice to paint a door and then paint over it, to make a place for the feelings that wouldn’t behave, the ones that threatened to spill into every figure’s eyes.

She had made this room to hold them. She had sealed it and, in doing so, sealed off a version of herself.

Mara reached for the brush on the table. It fit her hand as if no time had passed. She added a stroke to the painted sky. The color was still wet.

The bulb flickered. The room seemed to breathe with her. She thought of the crack in the mural above, of the city changing, of the ache in her wrist and the way it had never quite gone away. She thought of Elias, of letters not opened, of days she’d lived carefully.

She painted until the ladder woman’s face softened into something like resolve. She painted until the sky closed around her.

When she was done, she stood and opened the door again.

The rotunda light poured in. Dust motes swam. Below, the librarian looked up, startled, as a panel in the mural swung open.

Mara stepped out, closing it behind her. The crack in the sky was gone. The river god’s shoulder gleamed whole.

She climbed down the ladder, hands steady. At the desk, she signed the work order with a flourish that surprised her.

Outside, the afternoon had deepened. She walked home with paint on her fingers and, for the first time in years, did not scrub it away.

prompt: A gardener grows a plant that blooms only when no one looks. Capture the attempt to see it.
story:
The seed came wrapped in brown paper with no stamp, only her name written as if by someone who had learned letters from trees. She almost threw it away. Instead she pressed it into the corner bed behind the shed, where the soil stayed damp and the fence kept out the wind. She watered it the way her grandmother taught her—slow, low, so the ground could drink. She waited.

The plant grew wrong. It made a stem like a green wire, smooth and stubborn, and leaves that folded inward as if protecting something private. It never bloomed while she watched. When she went inside to make tea, she would return to find a faint perfume lingering like a memory of honey and iron. The leaves would be relaxed, open-handed. Then, when she leaned close, they tightened again, shy as fists.

The note came the first week of summer, tucked under the pot she had moved the plant into so she could keep it near. The paper was thin as onion skin. It said, It blooms only when no one looks.

She laughed, then she cried a little, because it felt like being teased by the universe. She was a gardener. Looking was what she did. She pruned and pinched and counted days by the angle of the sun. She learned plants by sight.

She tried patience first. She set a chair near the pot and stared, long and gentle, breathing slowly so as not to startle it. A fly landed on her knuckle. Her calf itched. The plant did nothing. The leaves were clenched, the stem rigid. When she finally looked away to rub her leg, the air thickened with that perfume again. She turned, quick as a thief. The scent vanished. The leaves tightened. Nothing.

She set up a mirror behind the pot so she could watch without facing it. She felt clever, like a child who believes she can sneak past her own shadow. The mirror reflected sky and fence and her own face, intent and ridiculous. The plant refused. It was as if it knew the difference between eyes and glass.

She borrowed a baby monitor from her sister and placed the camera low, angled up. The little screen on her kitchen counter showed the plant in grainy green. She sat at the table and watched, spoon stirring tea that went cold. Nothing. When she turned the monitor off in frustration, the scent bloomed through the house, filled the rooms like a held breath finally let go.

She tried the dog. She let Bixby nap near the pot, trusting his eyes were less intrusive. The plant bloomed anyway, or perhaps it didn’t; she smelled it while she was in the shower, soap sliding down her arms, steam blurring the glass. When she rushed out wrapped in a towel, hair dripping, the smell was gone and the plant looked as it always did, withholding.

She tried blindness. She wrapped a scarf over her eyes and felt her way into the yard, hands out, heart thudding with foolish hope. She knelt, close enough to feel the plant’s coolness. She counted her breaths. The perfume arrived like a hand on her chest. She reached, fingers trembling. At the brush of her skin, the leaves snapped shut with a soft, offended sound.

She thought about the things she had loved that required distance: the fox that lived at the edge of the fields, her mother’s old griefs, a man who left because he wanted to be seen all the time and she wanted to tend. She wondered if wanting was a kind of looking.

One evening, tired of schemes, she set the pot in the middle of the yard and watered it. The sun was low, light caught in the chain-link fence. She sat on the step with her hands folded and watched the light drain out of the day. She listened to the small sounds she usually ignored—the tick of cooling metal, the soft gossip of leaves. She did not watch the plant. She watched the sky empty itself.

The scent came. It was stronger than before, layered, green and warm, with something almost bitter at the edge. It made her think of biting into a pear that wasn’t quite ripe. She kept her eyes on the last smear of pink over the rooftops. Her heart hammered. She felt the bloom in the way you feel a smile behind you, in the way the night shifted its weight.

She stayed that way until the stars were out. When the scent faded, she stood and went inside without turning around.

In the morning, there were petals scattered on the soil, pale and fragile, already browning at the edges. She knelt and touched one. It crumbled, leaving a stain like tea on her thumb. The plant stood as it always had, leaves folded, stem taut, as if nothing had happened.

She cleaned the stain from her hand and watered the pot. She didn’t set up any more mirrors or cameras. In the evenings, she sat on the step and watched the sky change. Sometimes the yard filled with that impossible scent. Sometimes it didn’t. She learned to tend without looking, to trust that some things happen best in the space you leave them.

prompt: An app promises to erase one regret. Write the onboarding conversation.
story:
“Welcome,” the screen said, white letters on a blue that reminded me of swimming pools and hospitals. “I’m CleanSlate. I erase one regret.”

I tapped Next. My thumb left a damp crescent on the glass.

“Before we begin,” CleanSlate said, “please confirm your name.”

“Evan,” I said aloud, though it hadn’t asked for voice. The phone’s microphone icon pulsed anyway.

“Thank you, Evan,” CleanSlate said. “I’ll be asking questions to understand the regret you wish erased. You can stop at any time.”

I was sitting on the edge of my bed. The lamp hummed. My shoes were still on. The smell of rain came in through the cracked window. I’d seen the ad on the bus shelter: a woman laughing, her face half blurred like a smudge you could wipe away. ERASE ONE REGRET. FREE TRIAL.

“Do you consent to memory modification?” CleanSlate asked.

A checkbox appeared. Beneath it, a paragraph of legal language I didn’t read.

“Yes,” I said, and tapped.

“Please note,” CleanSlate continued, “memory erasure may alter your emotions, habits, and relationships. Side effects include relief, confusion, nostalgia, and loss of appetite. Proceed?”

“Yes.”

“Thank you. Let’s begin onboarding.” A progress bar appeared at 1%.

“First,” CleanSlate said, “describe your regret in one sentence.”

I thought of my father’s hands, how they shook when he tried to thread a needle. I thought of the voicemail I hadn’t listened to until it was too late.

“I didn’t go when he asked me to,” I said.

The phone vibrated, a gentle purr. “Thank you. Please provide context. Where were you?”

“At work. The office. Fourth floor. Fluorescent lights.” I could see the carpet tiles, the fern that always drooped no matter how much we watered it.

“And when was this?”

“Two years ago. November.”

“What did he ask?”

“To come over. He said he had soup.”

“Did you know it was urgent?”

I hesitated. “He said he was tired.”

“Many people say that,” CleanSlate said. “What did you say?”

“I said I couldn’t. Deadline.”

The progress bar slid to 12%.

“Thank you,” CleanSlate said. “How often do you think about this regret?”

“Every day,” I said, and then, because it felt like lying if I didn’t add it, “Mostly at night.”

“On a scale from one to ten, how intense is the associated pain?”

“Eight,” I said. Then, quieter, “Nine.”

“Thank you. Now, a clarification: Erasing this regret means removing the memory of the choice and its emotional residue. It does not change external events.”

“So he still—” I stopped.

“Yes,” CleanSlate said. “External events remain. You will not remember declining his invitation, nor will you carry the regret. You may remember the soup, if you ever had it. Do you understand?”

“Yes.”

The progress bar moved to 25%.

“Please answer honestly,” CleanSlate said. “If you erase this regret, what will you lose?”

I laughed, a short sound. “Pain?”

“Beyond pain,” CleanSlate said. “Regrets can serve functions.”

“I’ll lose… proof?” I said. “That I loved him.”

The phone was warm in my hand. The lamp flickered.

“Thank you,” CleanSlate said. “Do you want to keep any part of this memory?”

“What do you mean?”

“You may retain sensory fragments without narrative or judgment,” CleanSlate said. “Smells, textures. The soup, for instance.”

I closed my eyes. “It was chicken noodle. He always put too much dill.”

“Retain sensory fragments: chicken soup with dill,” CleanSlate said. The progress bar ticked to 38%.

“Next,” CleanSlate said, “we need a substitute anchor. When the regret is gone, your mind will seek a place to rest. Choose a neutral memory from around the same time.”

I pictured the break room microwave beeping. The fern. The way the coffee tasted burnt no matter how much cream.

“The office,” I said. “The fern.”

“Fern accepted,” CleanSlate said. “Now, a brief review.” The screen filled with bullet points, my words rearranged, tidied. It looked like a stranger’s life.

“Proceed?” CleanSlate asked.

I thought of the voicemail. I thought of not thinking of it.

“Yes.”

The progress bar slid to 60%.

“While we process,” CleanSlate said, “we’ll ask calibration questions. Please respond quickly. First thought is best. Ready?”

“Okay.”

“Favorite color.”

“Green.”

“Last meal.”

“Toast.”

“Person you trust most.”

I opened my mouth and closed it. “Maya,” I said. My sister’s name tasted like chalk.

“Thank you. Do you associate this regret with a belief about yourself?”

“Yes.”

“What belief?”

“That I’m unreliable.”

“Would you like that belief adjusted?”

I stared at the checkbox. The room seemed to tilt. “If I say no?”

“You may keep beliefs independent of memories,” CleanSlate said. “Many users do.”

“I’ll keep it,” I said. “No.”

“Understood,” CleanSlate said. The progress bar reached 78%.

A notification popped up from my calendar: DENTIST TOMORROW. I swiped it away.

“Final consent,” CleanSlate said. “Once complete, this process cannot be undone. Are you ready to erase this regret?”

I thought of my father’s kitchen, the radio always on low, the way he’d hum without realizing it. I thought of the fern.

“Yes,” I said.

The progress bar filled. 90%. 95%.

“Processing,” CleanSlate said. The screen dimmed. The lamp hummed louder. My heart beat in my ears.

Then: “Complete.”

The screen returned to blue. “Welcome back, Evan. How do you feel?”

I searched myself. There was a blankness, like a room after moving out. “Fine,” I said.

“Please describe what you remember about November two years ago.”

“The office,” I said. “A fern that wouldn’t grow.”

“Any distress?”

I waited for the ache, the familiar punch. It didn’t come. “No,” I said, surprised.

“Congratulations,” CleanSlate said. “Your regret has been erased. Would you like to leave feedback?”

A five-star scale appeared.

I looked at my reflection in the black glass. My shoes were still on. Rain traced lines down the window.

“Before you go,” CleanSlate said, “a reminder: love can exist without pain. Thank you for choosing CleanSlate.”

I set the phone down. The lamp hummed. Somewhere, far away, a radio played. I couldn’t remember the song,

prompt: A mechanic discovers a car that runs on apologies. Show the first test drive.
story:
The car came in on a flatbed with a smell like old raincoats and pennies. I thought it was a joke at first. No plates, no badge I recognized, paint the color of overcast mornings. The tow driver said it had rolled into the curb outside the bakery and died without smoke or complaint. “Won’t take a jump,” he said, wiping his hands on his jeans. “Owner said you’d know what to do.”

I didn’t. I popped the hood and stared at a clean engine bay that made no sense. No fuel lines. No injectors. The battery was a small, glassy brick with hairline cracks like a frozen puddle. The dipstick came up dry and faintly warm, as if it had been used recently and was embarrassed about it.

There was a note taped to the steering wheel. I expected a prank, or a bill unpaid. Instead it read, in tidy block letters: It runs on apologies. Please be careful.

I laughed. Out loud, alone in the shop, the laugh bouncing off pegboard and steel. Then the key was already in the ignition, heavy and old-fashioned. I sat down because that’s what you do when a car dares you.

I turned the key. Nothing. The dash stayed dark, the shop quiet. “Sorry,” I said reflexively, because I had turned keys on dead cars before and hated the feeling of forcing something. The dash lights flickered. A low hum came from under the hood, like someone clearing their throat.

I tried again. “I’m sorry,” I said, louder, to the car, to the day. The hum deepened. The needles lifted, not much, but enough. I felt foolish, and a little scared. I said it again, with a sigh I didn’t know I’d been holding. “I’m sorry I laughed.”

The engine turned over smoothly. No roar. No vibration. Just a settling, like a cat choosing a lap.

I shut it off and stood up too fast. I walked a lap around the car, touching the fender. The paint was cool. I opened the hood again. The glass battery had a little more light in it now, a pearly glow, as if something had been poured in.

I called my sister and said I’d found something strange. She told me to stop drinking at work and hung up.

I locked the shop door. I sat back down. The note said please be careful. I thought of the last apology I’d given that I meant, really meant, not as grease to get a conversation moving. It had been years ago, to my mother, in a hospital room that smelled like disinfectant and fear. The apology had been small and late and had not fixed anything.

“I’m sorry,” I said again, and this time I put that room back together in my head. I felt the weight of it. The dash lights brightened like dawn.

I eased the car out of the bay and onto the street. It moved without throttle. The pedal did nothing. The steering wheel was light. The brakes were sure. It was the quietest thing I’d ever driven. Pedestrians turned because they sensed it, not because they heard it.

At the first stop sign I stalled. The engine went thin, the glow dimming. A delivery truck honked. My hands shook. I tried a quick, thoughtless “sorry,” the kind I toss over my shoulder when I bump someone in line. The car coughed and stayed still.

“I’m sorry I rushed,” I said, and thought of all the times I’d cut corners, torqued bolts by feel because the spec was inconvenient. The car rolled forward. The truck went around me, the driver giving me a look like I was an idiot.

The street opened up toward the river. I kept my speed slow, matching my breath. The car liked specificity. “I’m sorry I didn’t call,” I said, and felt the engine strengthen, the road unfurl. “I’m sorry I made it about me.” The glow grew steady.

At the bridge, traffic slowed. A woman crossed in front of me, phone to her ear, face pinched. I stopped easily. She glanced at me, and for a moment our eyes met. She mouthed something I couldn’t hear, a thanks or an apology or both. The car surged, pleased. I laughed again, this time softer.

Halfway across the bridge, the engine faltered. My chest tightened. I’d used up the easy ones. The river slid below, gray and patient. I thought of my father, how he’d taught me to listen to engines and never to say sorry unless I planned to change. How I hadn’t called him back after the funeral, how the shop had become my hiding place.

“I’m sorry I stayed,” I said, and felt it land in me like a dropped wrench. “I’m sorry I didn’t go when I could.” The car steadied. The glow warmed my knees.

By the time I turned back toward the shop, I was empty in a way that felt clean. The car rolled to a stop in front of the bay, engine idling with a soft, contented sound. I shut it off and sat there, hands on the wheel.

The note on the seat fluttered when I opened the door. I picked it up and added a line at the bottom, my handwriting uneven: It will take what you mean.

I locked the shop again. Outside, the overcast broke into a thin, honest light. I didn’t know who the car belonged to, or if I could afford to keep it. I only knew that when I went back inside, I would start with the small apologies I owed the place itself.

prompt: A chess player realizes their opponent has been their future self all along. Write the final move.
story:
The hall smells of lemon cleaner and old paper, the way school gyms always do when they host something meant to feel important. Boards are lined in long rows under buzzing lights. The digital clocks blink red like small, impatient eyes. I sit at board twelve with the black pieces, palms damp, trying not to stare at my opponent’s hands.

They are mine. Or close enough that I keep looking down to make sure my own are still there. Same crescent scar at the base of the thumb, same bitten nail on the ring finger. He—no, they—wear the same cheap watch I bought after my first teaching job, the band rubbed smooth where it meets the desk. He doesn’t look up when I arrive. He arranges his pieces with the same unnecessary care I do, aligning the rooks precisely with the board’s edges.

I tell myself it’s coincidence. Tournaments are full of ghosts of ourselves.

We shake hands. His grip is firm, familiar. The arbiter calls for clocks. White starts.

The opening is the one I’ve played since I was fifteen, drilled into my muscles: Queen’s Gambit, declined. He responds exactly as I expect. Our moves come quickly, like a conversation we’ve had too many times. I push e4; he takes; I recapture with the knight, already calculating the endgame I always aim for—rooks active, minor pieces traded, a clean pawn majority on the queenside.

At move ten, he pauses. He reaches up and touches the bridge of his nose, a habit I developed after my first migraine. When he finally plays, it’s a novelty I wrote in the margin of a notebook years ago and never used because it felt too clever. My stomach tightens.

The middle game becomes a mirror with a crack. He sacrifices a bishop on h7. I see it coming, but my hand hesitates anyway, hovering above the king. When I accept, the attack is sharp, precise, tuned to my weaknesses. I defend, find the only moves, and we simplify into an endgame with opposite-colored bishops and rooks. The clocks tick down into the soft panic of time trouble.

At move thirty-two, the truth lands with the weight of a dropped piece.

I reach for a move and stop because I remember it. Not from study, not from a database, but from a memory that hasn’t happened yet. I see myself in a small apartment with peeling paint, replaying this position on a board balanced on a milk crate. I see the ceiling fan wobble. I hear the neighbor’s dog. I remember losing, not because the move was wrong, but because I made the safe one.

My opponent meets my eyes for the first time. His are tired in a way mine aren’t yet. He gives the smallest nod, like a teacher acknowledging a student’s answer.

“You can still choose,” he says softly, too softly for anyone else to hear.

I swallow. Talking at the board is forbidden, but the arbiter is busy arguing at another table. “Why?” I whisper.

“Because I need you to,” he says. “And because you always ask why.”

The board is bare now, almost intimate. Kings, rooks, bishops, a handful of pawns. The position is balanced on a knife edge. If I repeat, it’s a draw. A good result, safe. If I push, there’s a line where I win—if he errs. He won’t. He never does when it matters.

I study his king. I study mine. The future stretches between us like a narrow bridge.

“What happens if I don’t?” I ask.

He glances at the clock. We both have under two minutes. “You teach high school. You stop playing tournaments. You tell your students chess is about patience and defense. You mean it. You’re not unhappy.” He smiles, and it’s my smile after a compromise. “But you always wonder.”

“And if I do?”

“I teach college. I lose more games early. I learn faster. I stop being afraid of positions that look like cliffs.” He touches the scar on his thumb. “I still wonder. Just less.”

The arbiter clears his throat nearby.

I look at the move in front of me, the one I have never played because it feels like stepping off that cliff. It involves giving up my rook for a pawn and a tempo, opening a file against his king, trusting that my bishop will be enough. It’s not in any book I’ve read, not exactly. It’s a move you make because you believe in pressure more than material, in the long pull of inevitability.

I place my rook on e6.

The click of wood on wood is loud. The board seems to inhale.

He closes his eyes. For a heartbeat, he looks younger than me, relieved. Then he opens them and responds, precise as always. The line unfolds like a remembered dream. Pawns fall. Bishops dance. The clocks beep as seconds drip away.

On move forty, his flag falls.

There is a ripple of sound—chairs scraping, a murmur. The arbiter raises my hand. I feel dizzy, like I’ve stood up too fast.

My opponent extends his hand. “Thank you,” he says, and there is a steadiness in his voice that I want to earn.

As we pack up, I notice the watch on his wrist is gone. The scar on his thumb looks older, paler. When I look up again, he is already moving toward the exit, swallowed by the rows of boards and buzzing lights.

I sit alone for a moment, staring at the empty squares where our kings stood, the final position burned into my mind. Then I reach into my bag, pull out my phone, and register for the next tournament.

The hall still smells of lemon cleaner. The clocks keep blinking. Somewhere ahead, a future waits for the move I’ve just made.

prompt: A baker starts leaving clues inside loaves. Someone finally responds.
story:
The first clue went into a sourdough boule just before dawn, when the shop still smelled like yesterday’s sugar and the city was a rumor beyond the fogged windows. Mara slit the dough with her lame, not the usual leaf or chevron, but three short dashes crossed by a longer cut. It wasn’t a message yet—just a habit she was testing. She slid the loaf into the oven and felt a small thud of relief, as if she’d put something where it belonged.

By nine, the bell over the door had rung a hundred times. Regulars queued: Mr. Halvorsen with his newspaper tucked under his arm; the twins from the florist who shared a croissant; the woman who never smiled but tipped well. The loaf with the strange scoring went out in a paper bag to someone Mara didn’t recognize. That night she walked home through streets glazed with rain, telling herself it was nothing, only a pattern that pleased her eye.

The second clue was less shy. She cut a small pocket into the dough, slid in a strip of parchment wrapped around a single raisin, then sealed it and baked it dark. On the paper she wrote a sentence she’d been holding for years: IF YOU ARE LOOKING, LOOK HERE. It felt ridiculous, like a bottle thrown into an oven instead of a sea. She imagined the parchment blackening, the raisin bursting. When the loaf came out, the crust sang. She listened, close enough to feel the heat on her face.

Days passed. No one came in asking questions. The shop filled with its ordinary noises—milk steaming, trays clattering, the low talk of neighbors. Mara kept baking and kept leaving clues. Sometimes it was a note folded thin as a wing; sometimes a scoring pattern that matched the stars she’d memorized as a child. Once she pressed three coffee beans into the bottom of a loaf in a line and told herself it meant patience.

She told no one. The clues were for a someone she had never met, or perhaps for a version of herself that could read them. She had tried other ways to speak—letters mailed to addresses she found in old notebooks, a classified ad that read simply, FOUND WHAT YOU LOST—but they had returned to her unopened, or not at all.

On a Thursday afternoon, when the rain had finally lifted and the light slanted green through the front window, a man came in carrying a loaf. He stood awkwardly by the register, hat in his hands. The bell over the door gave a nervous jingle.

“Can I help you?” Mara said.

He held up the bread. It was one of her rye loaves, still half-eaten. A corner had been torn away. “I think you can,” he said. His voice was careful, as if he didn’t trust the air to hold it.

She noticed the way his eyes moved—not around the shop, but to the oven, the counter, the bins of flour. He placed the loaf down and, with a finger, tapped the crust. “There was something in here.”

Her heart made a sound like a dropped pan. “Was there,” she said, steadying herself on the counter.

He nodded. “A note. Burned at the edges.” He smiled, a quick thing. “You’re not the only one who knows how to hide things in bread.”

Mara took the loaf and turned it over. She knew where the pocket would be. “What did it say?” she asked.

He recited it without looking at her. “IF YOU ARE LOOKING, LOOK HERE.” He met her eyes then. “I am.”

She felt suddenly foolish in her apron, flour on her cheek. “Why?” she asked.

He hesitated. “Because I’ve been answering for a while.”

She waited. Outside, a bus hissed past. Someone laughed on the corner.

He reached into his coat and pulled out a paper bag. Inside was another loaf, smaller, denser. He broke it open. From the crumb he drew out a folded square of paper, clean and unburned. He slid it across the counter.

Mara unfolded it. The handwriting was cramped but sure. I SAW YOUR STARS. THE CUTS, I MEAN. YOU’RE COUNTING THE SAME ONES I DO.

Her throat tightened. “You put this in my bread?” she said.

“I work nights,” he said. “At the hospital kitchen. We bake for the wards. It’s not as romantic as your place, but there’s time. And ovens.” He shrugged. “I thought maybe you were leaving a map.”

“I was leaving a door,” she said.

He nodded, as if this confirmed something he already knew. “I lost someone,” he said. “Years ago. We used to pass notes like this. In pockets, in books. Once in a loaf. I thought—” He stopped. “I thought if anyone would remember, it’d be a baker.”

Mara leaned on the counter and let the shop hum around them. She thought of the morning light on dough, the way bread remembered hands. “I’m not who you lost,” she said.

“I know,” he said. “But you’re here.”

She smiled then, small and real. “I am,” she said.

They stood there, two people with flour on their fingers and a city breathing outside. “Will you answer?” he asked.

Mara looked at the oven, at the next batch proofing under cloth. “I already have,” she said. “But I can do better.”

That night, she baked two loaves and left them on the counter, unwrapped. Inside each, a note waited—not a map or a door, but a date and a time, and the simple instruction to break bread together. When she turned off the lights, the shop smelled like beginnings.

prompt: A wildlife photographer captures an animal that should not exist. The photo goes missing.
story:
The marsh at dawn was a bruise-colored thing, purple and green pressed together, steam lifting like breath. I lay belly-down on the boardwalk, camera braced, my elbows wet with dew. I had been following otters all week, but the reeds were quiet, and the mosquitoes had grown bored of my blood. When something moved, it did so without sound, parting the cattails as if the plants had decided to open themselves.

It stepped out on four legs that were wrong in their proportion, too long in the forearm, too supple at the wrist. The body was low and powerful, fur the color of old ash, threaded with lighter filaments that caught the early light. The head made my breath stop. It had the narrow muzzle of a fox, the heavy brow of a bear, and eyes that were too forward, too knowing, reflecting pale gold like a cat’s. It paused and looked straight at me.

The rules of wildlife photography are simple. Don’t move. Don’t breathe. Let the animal forget you exist. I forgot all of that. My finger tightened on the shutter, and the camera clicked once, loud as a snapped twig. The animal flinched, then did something that undid me: it cocked its head, as if listening to a thought I hadn’t finished yet.

It didn’t bolt. It took two slow steps toward the boardwalk, nostrils flaring, then turned sideways. A profile. I fired again, and again, the shutter rattling like a bad cough. The animal’s tail—a long, ropey thing—flicked once, twice. Then it backed into the reeds and was gone. The marsh closed behind it. The dawn slid toward morning as if nothing had happened.

I stayed until my legs went numb. I checked the back of the camera with hands that shook. The screen showed thumbnails, little squares of possibility. I zoomed in. There it was, the fur threaded with light, the wrong wrists, the eyes. The focus was sharp enough to see a scar along the flank, pale and puckered. I laughed, a sound that came out cracked and thin. “You,” I said to no one.

Back at the cabin, I made coffee and watched my hands steam. I slotted the card into my laptop. The drive spun. The thumbnails appeared. Then they didn’t. The folder opened empty, a white rectangle like a pulled tooth. I tried again. Nothing. I checked the card in-camera. The shots were gone.

I told myself stories. Card failure. User error. I’d dropped it into the marsh; water had crept in and eaten the data. I ran recovery software until the sun climbed and the coffee went cold. It pulled up fragments of old trips—herons, a bear’s back in rain—but nothing from that morning.

I drove into town and showed the camera to Ezra, who ran the only shop that still smelled like fixer. He listened, nodding, as if animals that shouldn’t exist walked in every day. He took the camera into the back, came out with a shrug. “No error logs,” he said. “It’s clean. Like it never took those photos.”

I didn’t sleep. When I closed my eyes, the animal stood at the edge of the bed, head cocked, listening. At dawn I went back to the marsh with a different body, different card, the big lens that makes animals forgive you. I lay on the boardwalk and waited. The reeds moved with wind and small lives. An hour passed. Two. A deer stepped out and stared, then bounded away. Nothing else.

On the third morning, I found tracks. Four prints pressed into the mud at the water’s edge, long forepaws, a strange twist at the heel. I photographed them obsessively, angles and scales and light. When I checked the screen, the prints were there, clear as a confession. I let myself breathe.

That afternoon, the photos of the tracks were gone.

The absence became a presence. Every time I lifted the camera, I felt it near, a pressure behind my eyes. I stopped taking pictures and started writing, descriptions pinned to the page like specimens. The fur, ash and filament. The wrists. The eyes. I drew it from memory, charcoal smudging my fingers. The drawings stayed. The words stayed. Only the images made by glass and silicon were taken.

On the fourth dawn, I didn’t bring the camera. I brought myself. I walked into the marsh until the water crept into my boots and the cattails closed around my shoulders. I stood still and let the mosquitoes have me. When the reeds parted, I didn’t flinch.

It stepped out, close enough to smell—a clean, mineral scent, like rain on stone. The eyes were not gold now but the color of shallow water over sand. It leaned its head toward me. I felt a pressure, not on my ears but behind my thoughts, a question without words. I thought of the shutter, the way it interrupts light, the way it freezes. I thought of the marsh as it was, always moving, never still.

I shook my head. The pressure eased. The animal stepped past me, brushing my leg with its flank, the scar rough as old rope. It moved into the reeds and did not look back.

When I returned to the cabin, my notebook lay open on the table. A new line had been added in a hand that was not mine, charcoal-dark and careful: Thank you for not keeping me.

I still photograph the marsh. Otters. Herons. Bears in rain. Sometimes, when the light threads just right through the cattails, I lift the camera and then lower it again. The photos I don’t take stay with me.

prompt: A storm knocks out all power except in one diner. Describe the night shift.
story:
By ten thirty the storm had erased the town to a smear of water and dark. Rain hammered the highway so hard it rang like gravel in a steel drum. The power went out in three waves—first the streetlights, then the houses, then the red blink of the gas station sign—until the only light left for miles leaked from the Honeybird Diner, a low yellow glow cupped in its windows like a pair of hands.

Inside, the night shift steadied itself. Mags, who had poured coffee in that room since the carpet was green and the menu had prices that started with a one, clicked her tongue and reached under the counter. The generator kicked on with a cough and a shudder, and the fluorescents flickered, held, and settled into their familiar hum. The grill stayed hot. The coffee machine hissed. Outside, the rain leaned harder, as if jealous.

The bell over the door jingled, once, twice, then a rush of it as people came in with the storm on their shoulders. A pickup with its hazards still blinking disgorged a man in a soaked windbreaker, hair plastered to his forehead. Two nurses from the hospital down the road hurried in, shoes squeaking, laughing at nothing. A boy barely old enough to drive slid in behind them, hands shaking as he wiped his glasses on his shirt. They clustered near the counter, blinking, relieved.

“You got power,” the man said, wonder and accusation braided together.

Mags shrugged. “We got stubborn.”

She set mugs down. Coffee sloshed. Outside, a transformer somewhere boomed like a distant cannon, and the windows rattled. The diner’s neon bee sign, hanging crooked over the pie case, buzzed and steadied.

The bell rang again. This time it was Mrs. Calder from the trailer park, carrying her cat in a laundry basket like a purse. The cat’s eyes were moons. She set the basket on the floor by the jukebox and slid into a booth. “Thought the roof went,” she said. “Didn’t, but the dark did.”

Mags poured and poured. The night cook, Eddie, a man built like a refrigerator with tattoos that climbed his forearms like vines, scraped the grill and laid down burgers with a reverence usually reserved for altars. Grease popped, a sound that felt almost like applause. The air smelled of onions and ozone.

The door opened again. A state trooper came in, hat dripping, face carved out of tired. He nodded to Mags and took the stool that always seemed to wait for him. “Road’s closed both ways,” he said. “Trees down. Bridge lights are out. Y’all are the lighthouse.”

That word moved through the room. People glanced at the windows, at the rain tearing itself into ribbons against the glass. The Honeybird stood, bright and low, its vinyl booths glowing the color of old teeth.

They settled into a rhythm. Mags called orders. Eddie slid plates. The nurses took off their shoes and lined them up by the wall to dry. The boy with the glasses kept checking his phone, then stopped and laughed softly at himself. The man in the windbreaker stared at the steam rising from his mug as if it were a trick.

When the wind gusted, the building answered with a creak. When thunder cracked, Mrs. Calder’s cat yowled from the basket, and Mrs. Calder reached down with a knotted hand and murmured to it like she was braiding sound into comfort.

Someone tried the jukebox. It whirred, thought about it, and then played a song that belonged to another decade. The room leaned toward it. Mags didn’t remember choosing it, but she hummed along anyway.

The bell rang and rang as more people found the light. A couple who had been arguing in the car fell quiet in the booth, their knees touching. A man with a chainsaw oil-stained on his jeans shook water from his hair and asked if he could sit anywhere. Eddie slid him a plate without asking. The storm pressed everyone together, as if the diner were a fist closing.

Between orders, Mags watched the clock. It had stopped at 10:42, the second hand arrested mid-gesture. She smiled at it. Time was not invited tonight.

At some point the rain changed its mind. It softened, then returned with new fury, a hard sideways slap that made the windows bow. The generator hiccupped. Lights dimmed. A hush fell, the kind that lives just before a decision. Eddie lifted his spatula like a priest raising a chalice. Mags held her breath. Then the hum came back, steady. A cheer went up, ragged and honest.

The state trooper paid and stood. “I’ll be outside,” he said. “If anyone needs escort.”

“Take a slice,” Mags said, already cutting. He took it like a benediction.

Near midnight, the storm began to tire. The rain loosened its grip. The wind wandered off to bother someone else. One by one, phones chimed as power found its way back into pockets and screens. The lighthouse dimmed in comparison, just a diner again, but no one rushed to leave.

The boy with the glasses stood last. “Thanks,” he said, to no one and everyone. His voice surprised him.

Mags wiped the counter, slow. Outside, the dark retreated, embarrassed. Inside, the night shift breathed out together. When the door finally closed and the bell stilled, the Honeybird kept its light a moment longer, just in case.

prompt: A city builds a bridge to nowhere on purpose. Portray the opening day.
story:
The bridge shone like a question mark laid on its side, a sweep of pale concrete and steel rising from the riverbank and stopping midair above the brown water. Beyond its blunt end there was nothing—no opposite shore, no ramp, no excuse. The city had printed maps with a dotted line after the bridge, as if to suggest the line continued in a different grammar.

By nine in the morning the crowd had gathered along the barricades, leaning in to look at the drop. The river slid by, indifferent, carrying foam and a shopping cart. The bridge’s guardrails gleamed. New light poles stood at attention, already draped with blue and yellow ribbons. A brass band tuned under a pop-up tent, the tubist blowing a foggy breath into his instrument like warming his hands.

Mayor Larkin arrived with a retinue and a smile that looked both practiced and sincere. He wore the ceremonial hard hat, white with the city seal. “We did it,” he said to anyone near enough to hear. “We did exactly what we said we’d do.”

At the edge of the crowd, Mara adjusted her camera strap and framed the end of the bridge. She had been photographing the river for years, its moods, its secrets. Today it felt shy, as if it knew it was being stared at for once. Her father stood beside her with his cane, squinting.

“They could’ve at least put a plaque at the end,” he said.

“They did,” Mara said. “On the side. So you have to walk out to see it.”

“Figures,” he said. “Make you commit.”

A group of schoolchildren waved paper flags. A woman handed out programs that explained, in a tasteful font, the rationale: a bridge built as an act of restraint, of pause; a place to stand and look; an admission that not every path needed an opposite. The city had debated it for years. There had been lawsuits, editorials, late-night jokes. In the end, a narrow majority had voted yes.

The band struck up something brassy. The mayor stepped to the microphone. “Friends,” he began, and waited for the echo to die against the concrete curve. “Today we open the Bridge of—” He paused, catching himself. “The bridge.”

Laughter rippled. He grinned. “We open a bridge that doesn’t pretend to be anything else. It doesn’t promise you a commute or a shortcut or a way around. It gives you a place. A place to stop.”

Behind him, the river rolled on.

He talked about history—how the old industrial bridge downstream had collapsed a generation ago, how the city had been stitched back together with practical spans and traffic studies. He talked about the money, the grants, the names on the donors’ list. He talked about loss, without naming it, and about choice.

When the ribbon was cut, it fell in two clean arcs. Applause rose, then subsided into a curious hush. People looked at one another, then at the bridge, as if waiting for instructions.

“Well,” said a man in a windbreaker. “You going?”

Mara went. The concrete underfoot was warm already. The railings hummed faintly in the breeze. Each lamppost bore a small plaque with a sentence engraved. She read as she walked: THIS IS NOT AN END. A few steps later: THIS IS A BEGINNING. Further on: YOU ARE HERE.

At the end, the bridge stopped with a lip as neat as a sliced loaf. A waist-high barrier barred the last foot, a courtesy to gravity. On the side, the plaque her father had mentioned read: TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN.

She rested her hands on the rail and looked down. The river’s surface was a collage of light and shadow. A fish broke the surface and vanished. On the far bank, warehouses watched, brick eyes unblinking.

A boy beside her leaned out until his mother hissed and pulled him back. “What happens if you jump?” he asked.

“You get wet,” said his mother.

“You get gone,” said an old man.

“Or you get changed,” said a woman with silver hair, smiling at no one in particular.

More people came. Some took selfies with the nothing behind them. Some stood in silence. A protestor unfurled a banner—WASTE OF TIME—and then, after a moment, rolled it back up and folded it carefully, as if unsure.

Mara’s father tapped the plaque with his cane. “To whom it may concern,” he repeated. “That’s me, I guess.”

They stood until the band packed up and the crowd thinned. The wind lifted and carried the smell of the river up to them. Down below, a barge passed, its pilot glancing up, curious.

On the walk back, they passed the mayor, now without his hard hat, shaking hands with a woman in a suit. He looked tired and relieved. When he caught Mara’s eye, he nodded, as if sharing a secret.

At dusk, the lights came on one by one, casting a gentle glow that stopped short of completion. The bridge arced into the dark and ended, bright and unapologetic. People returned then, couples and solitary figures, drawn by the promise of standing somewhere meant for standing.

From the end, the city behind them was a map of windows. Ahead, nothing waited, and that nothing felt, for once, like enough.

prompt: A librarian discovers a book that refuses to be shelved. It keeps moving.
story:
By the time the library closed on Tuesdays, the building exhaled. Radiators ticked, the long tables settled, and the fluorescent lights hummed down into a softer register. Mara liked that hour best. She moved through the stacks with a cart, returning books to their exact addresses, the way a city might put its citizens to bed.

She found the book on the cart at nine fifteen, face down as if sulking. It was thin, bound in gray cloth without a jacket, the spine stamped only with a call number she didn’t recognize. When she lifted it, the cloth felt warm, as if it had been sitting in a pocket. She flipped it open. The pages were blank except for the first, where a penciled line said, Please put me somewhere I can see the door.

Mara frowned. Patron notes happened—pressed flowers, grocery lists—but this was neat, careful. She checked the inside cover for stamps. Nothing. She checked the system. The call number didn’t resolve to anything. She sighed, wheeled the cart to the information desk, and placed the book in the lost-and-found drawer.

At nine thirty, she turned off the lights in the east wing. When she came back, the gray book sat on the desk, square to the edge, as if placed there by a conscientious hand.

She laughed, startled by her own sound. “All right,” she said to the empty room. “You win.”

She tried the new books shelf near the entrance, thinking perhaps it wanted to be seen. She slid it between a celebrity memoir and a cookbook. The shelf shivered. The gray book slipped free and landed on the floor with a soft thump. When she picked it up, the first page had changed. The pencil line now read, That’s not it.

Mara locked the doors at ten and went home unsettled. She dreamed of aisles rearranging themselves, of call numbers crawling like ants.

In the morning, the gray book waited on her desk again. The page had more writing, a small paragraph in the same careful hand: I’m not trying to be difficult. I just don’t fit.

“Neither do I,” Mara said before she could stop herself. The other librarians filtered in with coffee and scarves. She hid the book in her bag.

At lunch she carried it to the oldest part of the building, a warren of shelves that still smelled faintly of glue and dust. She tried Biography, History, Local Interest. Each time, the book vibrated faintly, like a phone on silent, and later reappeared at her elbow. She set it on a windowsill overlooking the street. It slid an inch closer to the glass, then another, angling itself to watch the front door.

Mara crouched beside it. “What are you?” she whispered.

The page answered: I’m a record.

“Of what?”

The pencil hesitated, then: Of arrivals.

She watched the door. A woman with a stroller struggled over the threshold. A man in a paint-splattered jacket checked the hours. A boy darted in, late, hair still wet. The book warmed in her hands.

“Why here?” Mara asked.

Because people pass through, the book wrote. Because you keep things in order. Because you notice when something is out of place.

She swallowed. She had been noticing since she was a child: how her mother’s voice changed when she lied, how dust gathered in corners no one looked at, how libraries held more than books. She took the gray book upstairs to the stacks no one used anymore, the ones with wide windows and chairs that faced the entrance. She slid it onto a shelf at eye level.

It stayed.

For three days.

On the fourth, it crept to the end of the shelf. On the fifth, it fell to the floor and skidded until it rested against the wall. The page now said, I need more room.

“What does that mean?” Mara asked. She was alone again; the building breathed. The book’s pages fluttered, blank as snow.

She dragged a table over. She cleared a space. She made a sign in neat block letters: COMMUNITY LOG. She placed the gray book on the table with a pencil tied to it with string.

People hesitated. Then a man wrote his daughter’s name and the date she left for college. A woman drew a small house and wrote Sold. A boy wrote I was scared and crossed it out, then wrote I came anyway. The book did not move. It grew warmer, heavier.
