I tamped the grounds, locked the portafilter. As the espresso pulled, he spoke, softly, as though afraid of waking something.

“I don’t drink coffee for sustenance,” he said. “I drink it to remember mornings.”

I nodded, because that made sense in a way nothing else had tonight. I poured the shot into a wide mug, then uncorked the vial. The scent was iron and roses. I counted—one, two, three—and watched the liquid thread into the crema, darkening it to something like sunset.

I heated water to 65 degrees Celsius, exactly, because he watched the thermometer with reverence. I poured slowly, circular, the way my trainer taught me, the way my hands remembered even when my mind wandered. The surface shivered, then settled.

He watched as if I were performing a small mercy.

“Do you need sugar?” I asked, because habit is a powerful spell.

“No,” he said. “Sweetness comes later.”

I slid the mug across. He didn’t touch it right away. He inhaled, eyes closing. When he finally lifted it, he cradled it with both hands, as if warming something more than flesh.

He took a sip. His shoulders loosened. Color, if not blood, rose into his cheeks. “You have honored the order,” he said.

“Glad to hear it.”

He reached into his coat and produced a folded bill, older than most of my regulars. He left it on the counter, weighted with a coin that hummed faintly when I picked it up.

“I’ll come again,” he said. “If that’s permitted.”

“Sure,” I said. “We’re open late.”

At the door, he paused. “Next time,” he said, “perhaps you’ll have beet.”

“Maybe,” I said.

The bell rang. The café settled. The espresso machine clicked as it cooled. I rinsed the portafilter, thinking about mornings, and the ways we keep them alive.

prompt: A small town elects a new mayor who never shows their face. Suspicion grows.
story:
The first thing people noticed was how the victory speech ended before it began. On election night, when the old gym filled with folding chairs and the smell of burnt coffee, the moderator tapped the microphone and announced that Mayor-elect Alder would not be attending in person. Instead, a recording played through the tinny speakers.

“Thank you for your trust,” the voice said. It was calm, almost gentle, with a cadence that suggested careful thought rather than passion. “I look forward to serving you.”

That was it. No waving, no applause line. The recording clicked off, and the gym echoed with the scrape of chairs as people stood, murmuring. Someone laughed, thinking it a joke. Someone else swore.

In a town like Briar Hollow, population 2,143 if you counted the farms, a mayor was not a distant figure. The previous one, Connie Marks, had walked her dog past the bakery every morning and argued with Tom Reyes about potholes over cinnamon rolls. So when Alder didn’t appear at the swearing-in, or the first council meeting, or the ribbon-cutting for the new recycling center, people began to notice.

Council meetings went on anyway. Alder attended by speakerphone. The voice came through, steady and unhurried, answering questions, proposing motions. The councilors would look at the empty chair at the head of the table, its nameplate freshly engraved, and then back at one another.

“Any objections?” the voice would ask.

“No,” they’d say, after a pause.

At first, the changes were small and welcome. The library got extended hours. The streetlight on Maple that had flickered for years was finally fixed. Permits moved faster. Alder sent handwritten notes—real ink, real paper—thanking volunteers after the spring cleanup. People pinned them to fridges.

Still, the questions grew. At the diner, where the vinyl booths were patched with duct tape, Hank the mechanic leaned over his eggs and said, “You ever see them?”

Mara, who ran the diner, shook her head. “Heard them,” she said. “Called in when the freezer went out. Very polite.”

“Could be anyone,” Hank said. “Could be nobody.”

Rumors sprouted like weeds. Someone said Alder was disfigured, ashamed. Someone else said it was a woman pretending to be a man, or vice versa. Teenagers dared each other to stake out the mayor’s office after dark, but the lights were always off. The blinds never moved.

The first real trouble came with the quarry. The state wanted to expand it, chewing closer to the creek that ran behind the elementary school. Connie would have rallied the town. Alder scheduled a public forum.

People packed the high school auditorium, angry and scared. The stage lights came up, revealing a podium and, behind it, nothing. A microphone waited.

The voice filled the room. “I know this matters to you,” it said. “I grew up listening to that creek.”

“You grew up here?” someone shouted.

“Yes,” the voice replied, without hesitation.

“Then where are you?” another voice demanded.

There was a hush, thick as dust. On stage, the microphone hummed.

“I’m here,” the voice said. “Listening.”

Boos broke out. A man threw his program. The forum dissolved into shouting, and people spilled into the night, the issue unresolved. The next morning, though, the state announced it was withdrawing the proposal. No explanation.

Suspicion hardened into something like fear.

Mara was the one who finally decided to do something. She had lived in Briar Hollow all her life. She knew the back roads, the habits. She closed the diner early one Tuesday and walked to the mayor’s office, a squat brick building between the post office and the insurance agency. The door was unlocked.

Inside, it smelled of dust and lemon cleaner. The desk was tidy. A coat hung on the back of the chair, gray wool. A mug sat cold, with a ring at the bottom. On the wall hung old photographs of the town: the mill when it still ran, the flood of ’78, the high school football team from decades ago.

“Mayor?” Mara called.

No answer.

She moved behind the desk. In the drawer, she found files—carefully labeled, meticulous. In the bottom drawer, a stack of cassette tapes. Each was marked with a date and a brief note: Council Meeting. Thank You Notes. Quarry Response.

From behind her came the voice, not amplified now, but the same calm tone. “Please don’t touch those.”

Mara spun around. The room was empty.

Her heart hammered. “Where are you?” she whispered.

“Everywhere I need to be,” the voice said. “And nowhere that would make you comfortable.”

“People are scared,” Mara said. “They think you’re hiding something.”

“I am,” the voice said. “I’m hiding from becoming what you expect. A face you can blame. A body you can corner.”

Mara swallowed. “What are you?”

There was a pause. When the voice spoke again, it seemed to come from the walls, the photographs, the desk worn smooth by decades of elbows. “I am what happens when enough of you agree,” it said. “You voted for an idea. I am doing my best to be worthy of it.”

Outside, the clock tower chimed. Mara stood alone in the office, her reflection wavering in the glass of the framed photos.

When she left, she locked the door behind her. At the diner the next morning, Hank asked, “You find anything?”

Mara poured coffee. “No,” she said. “Just more of us than I expected.”

The town went on. The creek ran clear. The streetlights stayed lit. And the mayor never showed their face.

prompt: A child builds a model city that predicts real traffic. The city council calls.
story:
On the day the model started predicting traffic, Milo was supposed to be doing math homework. The workbook lay open on the carpet, numbers smudged by the heel of his hand, while he leaned over the plywood board his father had cut to fit under the bed. Cardboard towers rose from it like a city that had decided to live quietly. Roads were drawn in thick marker, intersections marked with bottle-cap traffic circles, and streetlights made from paperclips held yellow beads. Milo nudged a toy bus along Maple Avenue and stopped it before the bottle-cap roundabout.

He’d learned the city by heart. He’d built it from cereal boxes and catalog scraps, then refined it for months, adding lanes when the cars jammed, cutting alleys when they didn’t. He’d named it after nothing—just City. The rules were simple: every morning, before school, he’d set the cars where he thought they’d be, then wait. He kept a notebook with dates and times and little drawings of arrows.

That morning, the bus stalled where he hadn’t expected. He frowned and adjusted the roundabout, adding a wedge of cardboard to slow the entry. When he checked the clock—7:42 a.m.—he heard a siren far away, thin as a mosquito.

His mother called from the kitchen. “Milo. Shoes.”

At school, Mrs. Ortega arrived late and apologized. “Accident on Maple,” she said, placing her coffee down with a tremor. Milo’s pencil paused. He wrote a small check mark in his notebook’s margin.

The city didn’t work every day. It wasn’t magic; Milo didn’t believe in that. It was just careful watching. He knew the way delivery trucks came on Thursdays, how the middle school let out early on Fridays, how rain turned Fourth into a crawl. The model helped him see the patterns, like a map you could fold and unfold until it fit your pocket.

By October, the notebook was thick. Milo had begun adding tiny signs—no left turn, school zone—and when he did, the real streets seemed to listen. He changed a lane on the model and the next day there’d be a line of cones on the actual road, as if the city were trying his idea on for size.

He told his dad first, one evening as they glued windows onto a hospital. “It’s like the city copies me,” Milo said.

His dad snorted, but he leaned closer. “You’re seeing coincidence.”

“Watch tomorrow,” Milo said, and showed him the notebook.

The next day, the radio crackled about a detour exactly where Milo had drawn one. His dad didn’t snort again. He drove slower, thoughtful.

Word moved the way gossip does, bumping from parent to parent at the pickup curb, sliding into the local blog. A reporter came and took pictures of the model, crouching to get street level, asking Milo to move a fire engine so it looked dramatic. The article said “precocious” and “whiz kid.” Milo hated both words.

The call from the city council came on a Tuesday. The number on the caller ID had too many digits. His mother answered and listened with her mouth in a straight line, nodding as if the voice could see her. She covered the phone and whispered, “They want to meet you.”

At City Hall, the carpet smelled like old rain. The council chamber had seats like a theater, and microphones that breathed when you touched them. Milo set his board on a table that had a seal carved into it, and his city looked suddenly shy under the lights. The councilors leaned in. One woman with silver hair asked, “How do you do it?”

“I just watch,” Milo said. “And then I build.”

They asked about algorithms and data sets. Milo talked about the bakery truck and the crossing guard with the whistle. He showed them how a pinch point on his model made cars back up all the way to the bridge. The traffic engineer’s pen stopped tapping.

“Could you predict next week?” someone asked.

Milo hesitated. He saw his city at home, under the bed, quiet and safe. He saw the way people’s faces changed when the roads clogged, how anger made them honk and cut. He thought of his notebook, how it felt heavier lately.

“I could,” he said. “But it’s better if I don’t decide everything.”

They met again. They asked him to help reroute for a parade, then for construction, then for a storm. Each time, the city listened. Milo felt like he was standing on a bridge he’d built without knowing where it went. When he changed a street, a bus driver thanked him in the grocery store. When he didn’t, the radio complained.

One afternoon, Milo noticed something wrong. In his model, if he widened the road by the river, traffic got worse everywhere else. The city wanted more space, and the more space it got, the more it took. He erased, tried again. Same result. He wrote in his notebook until the pencil nub hurt his fingers.

At the next council meeting, he pushed the board back. “I think you should stop asking me,” he said. The microphones breathed.

The silver-haired woman frowned. “Why?”

“Because cities aren’t just roads,” Milo said. He thought of the crossing guard’s whistle, the bakery truck’s bread smell. “If you fix everything, people stop noticing each other.”

Silence. Then the traffic engineer nodded. “He’s right,” he said softly. “We can use this as a guide. Not a rule.”

They agreed, some reluctantly. Milo took City home. He slid it under the bed and didn’t touch it for a week. When he did, he added a park where there had been a shortcut. In the morning, the radio said traffic was slow, but the weather was good, and people were walking.

prompt: A traveler checks into a hotel where each room is a different decade. Choose one stay.
story:
The clerk slid the key across the counter with a practiced smile. It was brass, heavy, with a plastic tag that read 2047 in blocky black numbers.

“You’re in the forties,” she said. “Breakfast is complimentary. Checkout is flexible.”

“What time is it now?” I asked.

She tilted her head, as if listening to a distant clock only she could hear. “Now is always now here.”

The lobby smelled faintly of lemon polish and ozone. A grandfather clock stood against one wall, its face divided into rings labeled by decade instead of hours. I tried to watch the hands, but they never quite settled.

The elevator had no buttons. When I stepped inside, the doors slid shut and the floor hummed, smooth as a held breath. A moment later, the doors opened onto a hallway washed in pale light. The carpet was a soft gray that looked like it could heal itself if scuffed. Doors lined the hall, seamless and unnumbered except for small decade tags embedded beside the frames.

My key warmed in my hand as I approached the one marked 2047. The door recognized me before I touched it, sliding aside with a whisper.

The room was larger than it looked from the outside, or perhaps it adjusted to my expectations. The walls were a matte white that shifted subtly with the light, and a wide window overlooked a city I didn’t recognize. Towers rose like glass reeds, connected by skybridges threaded with silent traffic. Drones drifted in slow arcs, purposeful as birds.

A bed occupied the center of the room, low and wide, covered in fabric that rippled when I brushed it. To one side stood a small table with no visible legs, and atop it a clear slab that glowed when I approached.

“Welcome,” said a voice—not from the slab, not from anywhere I could point to. “Would you like the room configured for rest, work, or reflection?”

“Reflection,” I said, feeling faintly ridiculous.

The light softened. The window dimmed until the city became a suggestion, a watercolor. The bed firmed beneath my fingers.

I sat and noticed something on the table: a thin booklet, actual paper. The cover read GUEST ORIENTATION: 2040s. I opened it. The pages were dense with small print, but what caught my eye was a handwritten note tucked inside, yellowed at the edges.

If you’re reading this, you’re probably wondering what they got wrong, it said. I was too.

There was a name at the bottom, dated 2039. The future, apparently, had left notes for itself.

I spent the afternoon exploring the room. The bathroom mirror offered gentle suggestions—hydration, posture, breathing—until I asked it to stop. The closet contained clothes in fabrics that adjusted to temperature and mood; when I tried on a jacket, it warmed at the shoulders, as if in reassurance.

At some point, there was a knock. I opened the door to find a woman about my age, carrying a tray.

“Room service,” she said. “They said you might want something simple.”

The tray held a bowl of soup, steaming, and a small loaf of bread scored neatly down the middle. It smelled like onions and thyme.

“Is this… printed?” I asked, gesturing vaguely.

She laughed. “No. Grown. But don’t worry, it’s old-fashioned on purpose.”

I invited her in. She glanced around, nodding. “First time in the forties?”

“Is it that obvious?”

“You’re touching everything like it might vanish.”

I told her about the note in the booklet. She smiled, a little sadly. “People leave those. Sometimes they come back and read them, if they’re staying more than once. Memory gets… slippery.”

“What did they get wrong?” I asked.

She considered. “They thought we’d be calmer. That the answers would settle us.”

“And did they?”

She shook her head. “We just got better questions.”

After she left, I ate the soup by the window. The city outside brightened as evening fell, lights blooming along the bridges. I thought about the decade I’d left—my decade—and how certain we were that the future would be a straight line from our intentions.

I slept deeply. Dreams came in high definition: forests stitched back together, arguments resolved in public squares, the quiet relief of systems that worked. I woke once, disoriented, and the room murmured reassurance until my pulse slowed.

In the morning, breakfast arrived without a knock. Fruit that tasted like it had been picked minutes ago, coffee that adjusted itself after the first sip. Another note lay beside the tray, this one in my own handwriting.

You will miss this, it read. Not the technology. The sense that repair is possible.

I stared at it for a long time. I didn’t remember writing it.

Checkout was as simple as placing the key back on the table. The room dimmed, the walls smoothing to blankness. As I stepped into the hallway, I glanced back once more at the city, committing it to memory like a promise.

The elevator returned me to the lobby. The clerk smiled as if no time had passed at all.

“How was your stay?” she asked.

“Hopeful,” I said, surprising myself with how true it felt.

She nodded, as if that were one of the available amenities, and took the key. The grandfather clock ticked softly behind her, its hands circling through decades, never quite stopping on any one.

prompt: A filmmaker finds a reel that shows their life with a different ending. They screen it.
story:
The reel came in a dented metal can with my name written in pencil, the handwriting neat and old-fashioned, like my mother labeled jars of jam. I found it in the back room of the Pacific Arcade, where I was clearing out the remains of the lab before the landlord turned it into offices. The lab smelled the way it always had—vinegar and dust and the faint sweetness of fixer. Light slanted through the high windows and made the air look particulate, alive.

I weighed the can in my hands. It was 16mm, heavier than it should have been. There was no date. The pencil had pressed hard enough to score the lid. I don’t believe in omens, but I stood there longer than necessary, listening to the hum of the refrigerator and the city beyond the brick wall.

I threaded it onto the Steenbeck. The leader was white, unmarked. The first frames flickered into place, and I recognized the grain immediately, the way the highlights bloomed when the lens was wide open. It was my work. It was my apartment—no, my old apartment, before the pipes froze and the windows rattled like teeth. The kitchen table was where it had been, but the chairs were wrong, the legs thinner. On the table sat a bowl of lemons I never bought because I hated the way they went soft.

The camera moved with a familiarity that made my stomach tighten. It panned too quickly, like I always did when I was impatient, and landed on a man at the sink. He was me, five years younger, hair still dark at the temples. He turned and smiled at someone offscreen, a smile I recognized as the one I used when I was trying to be brave. “You’re late,” he said, and then laughed, because the person offscreen said something I couldn’t hear.

I watched for an hour before I stopped it. In that hour, I saw things I had never filmed: a morning run along the river where I had quit running after my knee gave out; a phone call where my sister didn’t cry; a night where I slept without the light on. The camera was always there, as if my hands had been steady enough to keep it.

At the end of the reel, the image cut to black on a sound that wasn’t there—a door closing, maybe, or a laugh. I sat in the dim and listened to the projector wind down. I felt the way I do at the end of a movie when the lights haven’t come up yet, when the world feels slightly adjustable.

I carried the can home on the bus, cradled on my lap. My apartment now was smaller, a one-bedroom above a bakery. I made coffee and set up the projector on the folding table. I texted no one. The walls were bare, the frames waiting for something to be worth hanging.

The second screening was worse, because I noticed the details that made it impossible. The jacket I wore in one scene was a gift from Mira, who had left me before she ever bought it. The scar on my wrist in another came from a cut I had avoided when I took the long way home that night. In the footage, I took the short way, the alley with the broken bottle. I winced in sympathy.

Halfway through, the reel did something strange. The camera turned outward. I was no longer the subject. The image showed a small theater, seats upholstered in green velvet, scuffed. The screen glowed with an image I recognized: my face, older, looking out. In the film, I was watching myself watch.

The ending was coming. I felt it the way you feel a storm before the clouds arrive. The scenes tightened, compressed. There was a hospital room that smelled like bleach even through the screen. There was my sister, hair pulled back, eyes red but dry. There was a doctor whose mouth moved with practiced sympathy.

I stood up. My knees knocked the table, and the projector wobbled. I thought of pulling the plug, of saving the ending like a jar unopened. But I had always believed in finishing what I started. That belief had cost me people. It had also given me work.

I sat back down.

In the final scene, I was in the theater again. The film-within-the-film reached its own end. The older me stood as the lights came up. He looked around, as if to see who else had come. The seats were empty. He smiled anyway, a small, private smile, and clapped once, softly, for the screen.

Then he walked down the aisle, past the exit sign, and out into daylight. The camera followed him through glass doors and onto a street I didn’t recognize, a street with trees that threw patterned shade. He paused, hand on the door, and turned back to look at the theater. The look wasn’t regret. It was acknowledgment.

The reel ran out. The leader flapped against the take-up reel, making a sound like applause if you wanted it to be.

I sat there a long time. Outside, the bakery downstairs closed, the sweet smell fading. I thought about the alley and the jacket and the lemons. I thought about the older me, clapping once in an empty room.

The next day, I carried the reel back to the Pacific Arcade. The landlord was there with a tape measure. I told him I’d take the projector and one shelf of chemicals, if he didn’t mind. He shrugged. “Take whatever,” he said. “No one wants this stuff.”

I threaded the reel again. I watched the ending once more, standing this time, as if my body needed to agree with the decision. When the leader came, I rewound it carefully. I labeled the can with a date—not a year, just a day—and put it on the shelf.

That night, I went the long way home. I bought lemons. I left the light off. The ending I had seen didn’t change what came before it, but it changed how I walked through the middle, as if somewhere ahead, a small theater waited, and I intended to arrive.

prompt: A news anchor can see the truth as subtitles over people's heads. Write their breaking news segment.
story:
The red light blinked on, and the studio brightened half a stop, the way it always did before the music hit. I straightened the stack of papers that existed mostly to keep my hands busy and smiled into Camera One.

“Good evening. We’re interrupting regular programming for breaking news.”

Above the camera operator’s head, where the boom mic cast a thin shadow, the subtitles unfurled like a ribbon caught in a breeze.

[He forgot his lunch. He is thinking about the egg salad.]

I swallowed. The gift—curse—had come to me six months ago, during a city council interview. Ever since, words I didn’t speak appeared over people, pale yellow sans-serif, as neat as closed captions. They were never metaphors. They were always, bluntly, the truth.

“In the last hour,” I continued, “an explosion at the Riverline Chemical Plant has sent a plume of smoke across the east side. Authorities say—”

The director’s voice crackled in my earpiece. “We’re rolling B-roll in ten.”

—“—authorities say there is no immediate danger.”

Above my own head, reflected faintly in the teleprompter glass, I saw nothing. It never showed me my own truths. That was a mercy.

We cut to footage of gray smoke boiling over the river, sirens threading through the sound. When we came back, the mayor stood beside me, tie too tight, jaw clenched.

“Mayor Collins,” I said, “thank you for joining us. Can you tell our viewers what happened?”

He leaned toward the desk, hands folded. Above him:

[We cut corners. The sensors failed. Don’t say the word benzene.]

“There was an industrial accident,” he said, voice steady. “Our first responders acted quickly. Air quality readings are within acceptable limits.”

[Acceptable if you don’t live east of Ninth.]

The camera tightened. Sweat beaded at his hairline.

“Residents are being advised to shelter in place,” he added.

[Because evacuation would admit fault.]

I nodded gravely. “How long should they expect—”

In my earpiece: “Wrap him.”

“—to stay inside?” I finished.

“An abundance of caution,” he said.

[For the lawyers.]

The red light flicked off. As the mayor was ushered away, his subtitles dissolved. I exhaled.

“Commercial,” the director said. “Then Dr. Patel.”

During the thirty seconds of ads, I drank water and tried not to think about the way the truth pooled around people, unavoidable as heat shimmer. When we came back, Dr. Anika Patel sat in the guest chair, hair pulled back, lab badge clipped to her blazer.

“Doctor,” I said, “you’ve reviewed the available data. What do you make of the situation?”

Above her:

[I am scared. The numbers are incomplete.]

She didn’t flinch. “We need more information,” she said. “But certain compounds—if present—can be harmful even at low concentrations.”

[Especially benzene.]

My pulse ticked up. “Harmful how?”

“Respiratory irritation. Long-term risks,” she said.

[Children. Pregnant people.]

The producer cut in. “We have the governor on line two.”

The screen split. The governor’s smile filled half the frame.

[Stay calm. Don’t mention donations.]

“Governor,” I said, “is the state mobilizing resources?”

“Absolutely,” he said. “We’re coordinating closely.”

[We are coordinating messaging.]

I felt the old itch behind my eyes, the one that came when the truth stacked too high. The ticker crawled with official statements. The phones lit up with viewer calls. I had a choice, every night: translate what I saw into the sanctioned language of news, or let the captions speak through me.

“Governor,” I said, “are there hazardous materials at Riverline that the public should know about?”

His smile tightened.

[If she says it, we’re sunk.]

“There are many materials,” he said. “All stored according to regulations.”

[Some of which were waived.]

“Mayor Collins told us air quality is within acceptable limits,” I said, keeping my voice level. “Doctor Patel, do you agree?”

Dr. Patel glanced at me, really looked, as if she sensed something under my calm.

[She sees it too? No. Focus.]

“I would urge caution,” she said. “Independent testing would be prudent.”

[Now.]

The director’s voice was urgent. “We’re getting reports of people smelling sweetness.”

Sweetness. The word hit like a bell.

Above the governor:

[That’s benzene.]

Above Dr. Patel:

[That’s benzene.]

Above the producer, who had leaned into frame by accident:

[Oh no.]

I felt the studio tilt. The subtitles weren’t whispers; they were facts, hanging there, waiting.

“Viewers,” I said, and my voice sounded like mine, “we are receiving reports of a sweet odor in the affected area. Doctor Patel, what could that indicate?”

She hesitated a fraction of a second.

[If I say it, my funding.]

“Certain aromatic hydrocarbons,” she said. “One common example is benzene.”

The governor’s face drained of color.

[She said it.]

“And what are the risks?” I asked.

“Immediate evacuation is recommended if levels are high,” she said.

[They are.]

The director swore in my ear. “Cut. Cut!”

The red light stayed on.

“Residents east of Ninth,” I said, “if you smell a sweet odor, leave the area if you can. Seek fresh air.”

Above my head, for the first time, a subtitle flickered into existence, faint but legible.

[This is why.]

The light went off. The studio fell into the ordinary chaos of cables and voices. The governor disconnected. Dr. Patel closed her eyes. Somewhere, sirens wailed.

I sat there, hands steady on the desk, watching the truths dissipate like smoke, and hoped they would reach people before the wind changed.

prompt: A mountain appears overnight outside a coastal town. Everyone reacts differently.
story:
The mountain rose where the sea had been.

At dawn the gulls wheeled and screamed as if someone had pulled the horizon up by its collar. From the boardwalk, people stared at a wall of rock that hadn’t been there when the bars closed and the tide went out. It was slate-gray and steep, its shoulders wrapped in low cloud. A smell of crushed stone and wet iron drifted over the town, mixed with kelp and diesel.

Marta Alvarez stood on her porch with her coffee cooling in her hands. She had lived on Pelican Street for thirty years, long enough to know every morning sound—the foghorn’s pulse, the shrimpers’ engines coughing awake. This morning the foghorn was quiet. The sea had been pushed back into a narrow, dark inlet, and beyond it the mountain blocked the sky like a held breath.

Her phone buzzed. The town alert chimed. “Stay calm,” it said. “Emergency meeting at the high school gym at nine.”

Down on the docks, Captain Roy Jensen laughed like a man at a good joke that would get better the more he told it. “Well I’ll be damned,” he said to no one in particular, slapping the rail of his trawler. “Always wanted a view.” He’d lost two nets to storms last winter. He imagined fresh streams spilling down that rock, trout where there had been mackerel. He imagined tourists paying to ride his boat to the base of it. “Change,” he said, and spat. “That’s just change.”

At the end of the pier, Lenora Pike pressed her palm against her chest as if to keep her heart from leaving. She had dreamed of this when she was a girl, a dark triangle rising from the water, solid and quiet, and her mother had told her not to tell anyone because dreams like that made people uneasy. She whispered a prayer she had learned in a church that no longer stood, one for patience and for listening.

The mountain had details you noticed only after staring too long: pale seams like old scars, ledges dusted with lichens already green as if they’d been waiting, a ribbon of water slipping down one flank and vanishing into a crevice. No smoke, no ash. It did not feel hot. It felt—Marta searched for the word—complete.

By nine the gym smelled of sweat and coffee and worry. The mayor stood with a microphone and said the words he had practiced: unprecedented, assessment, coordination. A geologist from the university clicked through slides showing fault lines that did not quite explain the thing outside. “It shouldn’t be there,” she said, and people laughed because laughter was easier than what followed.

A boy named Theo raised his hand. He was nine and had brought a notebook. “Does it have a name?” he asked.

There was a pause. Names mattered more than explanations sometimes. “Not yet,” the mayor said. “We’ll have a process.”

Outside, teenagers climbed the chain-link fence that marked the old cannery lot, phones out, chasing likes with the mountain behind them. The sheriff shooed them away, citing safety, citing unknowns. A woman from the yoga studio knelt on the asphalt and cried, her mat rolled under her arm, because the sunrise class had been canceled and she felt the day tipping wrong.

By noon, people argued. The fishermen wanted to blast a channel. The environmental group wanted it protected, an instant monument. The real estate agent posted listings with “mountain view” in bold. The insurance adjuster took photos and shook his head. The scientist asked for samples. The preacher rang the bell and preached about humility to a crowd that spilled into the street.

Marta closed the café early. The espresso machine hissed as if offended. She carried a tray of day-old pastries to Lenora, who lived alone in a house with a garden of stubborn roses. They sat on the steps and watched the clouds comb the mountain’s brow.

“It’s not angry,” Lenora said.

“You know that how?”

“Angry things move fast.”

In the afternoon, a path appeared. Or maybe it had been there all along. Children found it first, a zigzag of packed dirt and pale stone leading up from the inlet. Parents followed, then the rest, pulled by the simple fact that the mountain was there and had not gone away when everyone agreed it should have.

The climb was steeper than it looked. People stopped to catch breath, to argue, to help one another over a smooth place. The air smelled different as they went up, cleaner, edged with pine. Halfway up, Roy Jensen sat on a rock and took off his cap, staring at the town spread below like a toy he had once loved. “Huh,” he said, quietly.

At the top there was a shelf wide enough for the crowd to gather. The clouds parted, and the sun laid a hand on the stone. From there you could see the inlet curling like a question mark, the docks small and patient, the ocean beyond, unchanged and immense. No rumble, no revelation. Just a long view.

Theo wrote in his notebook. Lenora closed her eyes. The geologist took a sample and then put it back where she had found it. The mayor took a photo and did not post it.

As evening fell, people went down. They went back to stoves and boats and beds. Some slept badly. Some slept for the first time in weeks. The mountain stayed.

By morning, the foghorn sounded again, its low note threading around the rock. Marta opened the café and brewed coffee. Outside, the mountain caught the light and held it. The town adjusted its mirrors and its maps. And somewhere in the stone, water kept finding a way down, patient as always, as if it had been there all along.

prompt: A bookstore owner discovers a shelf that sells books before they are written. They use it once.
story:
On rainy mornings the bell over the door rang like a small apology. Miriam liked that. It meant the world knew it was intruding on a quiet place and felt a little sorry about it. Her bookstore, Spindle & Salt, sat between a locksmith and a nail salon on a narrow street that smelled of coffee grounds and damp wool. The shelves bowed with use; the floorboards spoke. Miriam had owned the shop for eleven years, long enough to recognize which creaks meant a customer and which meant the building settling its shoulders.

She discovered the shelf on a Wednesday when the rain came down as if it meant to erase the street. She was rearranging the back corner—where cookbooks went to retire and the poetry that frightened people—when she noticed an empty space where an endcap should have been. Not empty exactly. The space had depth without distance, like a mouth waiting to speak. When she stepped closer, a shelf slid into being, wood the color of old pennies, grain swirling in a way that made her eyes ache.

Books stood on it. Not many. Seven, she counted. Their spines were plain, unlettered, but warm under her fingers. She pulled one free. The cover was a muted blue, the paper thick. The first page read:

—This book will be written by—

And then, below, in a smaller, careful font: —If you choose to read, you choose to purchase.—

Miriam laughed, a short sound that bounced and fell. She had been alone too long, she thought. She turned the page.

The book was about a woman who ran a bookstore on a narrow street that smelled of coffee grounds and damp wool. It was written in the third person, brisk and exact. It knew the locksmith’s name (Rafael), the way the nail salon’s neon buzzed at dusk, the place under the counter where Miriam hid a tin of lemon drops. It knew the bell’s apologetic ring.

She closed the book and pressed her palm to the cover as if to keep it from breathing. Her heart had begun to knock against her ribs, not in fear exactly, but in recognition. She slid the book back into place. The shelf waited, patient.

All day, she sold nothing. Customers came in, shook umbrellas, browsed, left. The shelf hummed at the edge of her hearing, a refrigerator in another room. At closing, she turned the sign to CLOSED and stood with her back to the door.

She pulled a different book. The cover was green. Inside: a man named Daniel who had once loved a woman named Miriam but left town after an argument about a shelf that sold impossible things. The argument was described with painful precision, including the chipped mug and the way Miriam’s voice went flat when she was hurt. The last line of the chapter was unfinished, trailing off mid-sentence.

She put the book back harder than she meant to. Her hands were shaking now. She had not seen Daniel in four years. He had moved to Chicago, sent a postcard once, then nothing.

She did not read the other books. She turned off the lights and went home, carrying the rain with her. That night she dreamed of spines with no words, of shelves that breathed.

For a week, she avoided the back corner. She told herself the shelf was a trick of stress, a symptom of too much quiet. But she could feel it like a pulled tooth. On the seventh day, Rafael came in to get a key cut for a customer and lingered, as he did, by the register.

“You look tired,” he said.

“I found something,” she said, because sometimes the truth leapt out of her like a fish.

He raised an eyebrow. “In the back?”

She nodded. “A shelf.”

He smiled. “There’s always another shelf.”

She almost told him everything. Instead, she sold him a paperback and watched him leave. When the bell rang, she made her choice.

She went to the shelf and pulled the smallest book. The cover was red, the color of a stop sign. Inside, the pages were blank except for the last one. On it was a single paragraph:

—Miriam uses the shelf once.—

Below that, a price, printed neatly: $18.99.

She laughed then, a real laugh that loosened something in her chest. “Fine,” she said to the shelf, to the room, to whatever listened. She took the book to the register, rang it up, and put the money in the drawer. The bell rang as if she had opened the door.

She sat on the floor between the shelves and read the last page again. Using it once could be anything. Reading was using. Buying was using. She had already done that. Or perhaps the use was something else.

She thought of the green book, of Daniel, of the unfinished sentence. She thought of the blue book that knew her life with such care. She thought of the customers who came in looking for themselves and left with something adjacent.

Miriam stood. She took the red book back to the shelf. She slid it in, then reached for the green one. She hesitated, then placed her palm on the shelf itself. The wood was warm.

“I choose,” she said, and pulled the shelf out by its edge.

It came away like a drawer. The books tilted, then vanished, the space collapsing into ordinary air. The back corner held cookbooks and frightened poetry again. The hum stopped.

That evening, as she locked up, her phone buzzed. A message from an unknown number: Miriam? It’s Daniel. I’m in town. I was hoping we could talk.

She stood in the rain and smiled, not because she knew what would happen, but because she had decided what wouldn’t.

prompt: A competitive eater is invited to a feast that never ends. Describe their exit plan.
story:
I was halfway through the ninth course when I realized the plates were getting heavier.

Not heavier with food—heavier in the hand, as if the porcelain itself had weight, a gravity that pulled my wrists down. The table stretched away in both directions, a polished river of wood reflecting chandeliers that dripped light like honey. Every chair was occupied. Every mouth moved. Steam rose in tides. The smell was butter and salt and sugar braided together, a perfume designed to make hunger forget its own name.

“Impressive pace,” said the woman to my left. She wore a gown the color of claret and ate with a small silver spoon, never lifting her eyes from the plate. “You must be a professional.”

“I am,” I said, and took another bite. My jaw moved by habit. I had won belts and cash and a van with my name painted on the side. I knew how to portion pain, how to make the body lie to itself. This was supposed to be a publicity stunt. A feast. A dare. Eat as much as you want.

No one mentioned leaving.

When the servers returned, the plates were full again. My stomach rang with a dull bell. The clock on the far wall showed seven o’clock, its hands locked together like lovers.

“Intermission?” I asked the man across from me, a thin fellow with a waxed mustache. His plate held a roast pheasant that bled pink onto potatoes.

He smiled. “Why interrupt a good thing?”

I took stock. My pulse was steady. My breathing shallow but controlled. I had learned to listen for the small signs: the creeping numbness in the fingers, the way the room’s edges softened when sodium tipped the balance. I drank water when it came, though it tasted faintly of broth.

Between courses, the servers cleared nothing. They only added. A second table slid out from beneath the first, then a third, like a magician’s scarves. My exit plan began, as all good plans do, with denial. Surely there was a door. Surely the invitation included a polite goodbye.

I stood. The chair did not scrape. It clung to me, warm, as if it had been waiting.

“Sit,” said the woman in claret, kindly.

I sat. I ate. I listened. The sounds were rhythmic: fork to plate, swallow, sigh. Somewhere, a violin played the same eight bars again and again.

At course twelve, I stopped chewing. I let the food rest in my mouth, cataloged textures: crisp, yielding, gelatinous. I swallowed only what was necessary to keep the performance believable. That was the first rule: never tip your hand.

At course fifteen, I noticed the doors. There were four, evenly spaced, tall and arched, each painted with a different scene: a harbor, a forest, a city street at dawn, a simple white rectangle like an unmarked card. The servers passed by them without touching the handles.

I asked for a bathroom break. Laughter rippled, soft as napkins.

“You may,” said the thin man. “Between courses.”

“When is that?”

“Now,” he said, as another platter arrived.

I made my plan the way I had learned to make my body stretch: incrementally, painfully, with room for error. I would not outrun the feast. I would become inconvenient.

At course eighteen, I began to eat wrong. I chewed too fast, then too slow. I drank without eating. I ate without drinking. I asked for substitutions, sent plates back untouched. I spoke too loudly. I spoke too softly. I praised a dish until the servers blushed, then complained of its temperature. I dropped a fork and let it ring.

The violin skipped a note.

At course twenty-one, I vomited into my napkin with professional discretion and folded it closed. I kept my hands steady. I smiled. I apologized. The woman in claret’s spoon paused midair.

“That won’t do,” she said.

“Occupational hazard,” I said. “I’ll make it right.”

I stood again. This time, the chair resisted. I leaned forward, using the table’s edge as leverage, and felt the suction break with a wet sound. The room smelled briefly of ozone.

I walked to the doors. The harbor showed ships frozen in mid-wake. The forest’s leaves were motionless. The city street’s dawn never warmed. The white rectangle reflected my face, slick with sweat.

Behind me, cutlery stuttered.

I opened the white door.

There was a hallway the width of a bowling lane, tiled in clean, ordinary linoleum. Fluorescent lights hummed. A sign pointed left: KITCHEN. Right: RESTROOMS.

I went right. I locked myself into a stall and did what I had trained for but never loved. I emptied myself as much as I could, slow and controlled, counting breaths. When I finished, I rinsed my mouth and looked at my hands. They were shaking now.

Back in the hall, the humming seemed louder. I went left.

The kitchen was endless counters, endless pots, a factory of abundance. Food flowed from somewhere unseen. I found a breaker box on the wall, labeled neatly. MUSIC. LIGHTS. SERVERS. TABLE.

I flipped TABLE first. The floor shuddered. Somewhere, a collective gasp. I flipped SERVERS. The clatter stopped. I flipped MUSIC. Silence fell, deep and shocking.

I did not flip LIGHTS.

I ran back through the hall and into the white door. The feast was chaos—people standing, plates sliding, the thin man gripping the table’s edge like a lifeline. The doors painted with scenes were opening now, cracking.

I ran for the city street at dawn. The handle was cold. As I pulled, the woman in claret met my eyes. She looked hungry, finally.

“Eat,” she said.

“I’m full,” I said, and stepped into a morning that smelled like rain and nothing else.

Behind me, the door closed. The clock on the wall of a café across the street read seven-oh-two and was ticking.

prompt: A clock tower rings only when someone lies. The town falls silent.
story:
The clock tower stood in the square like a finger raised to hush the town. It was old, limestone blocks sweating lichen, the iron hands blackened by a century of sun. At the hour it would strike once, as any clock did. But between hours, it rang for only one reason.

Everyone knew this. Everyone learned it young.

The bell’s voice was not loud. It was a clean, exact sound, a single note like a spoon against a teacup, traveling through open windows and down alleys. When it rang, people froze. They looked at their shoes or at the sky. They did not ask who had lied, because they would know.

On the morning the town fell silent, Marta was slicing pears in her bakery. Syrup ran over her fingers. She told her apprentice, without thinking, “They’re sweeter this year.” The bell chimed once, not the hour. The knife slipped and nicked her thumb. Blood bloomed.

She laughed, too quickly. “I mean, they look sweeter.” The bell did not answer. Her apprentice, Jovan, kept his eyes on the dough.

After that, people learned to speak like they were stepping through glass. Or they stopped speaking at all.

The silence did not arrive at once. It crept. First, the usual lies fell away—the polite ones. “Fine,” said no one when they were not fine. “Tomorrow,” promised no one unless they meant it. Then the careful truths grew smaller, trimmed down to bone. “It’s cold,” someone would say, because it was. “Bread,” said at the bakery, pointing. The bell stayed quiet, patient.

At the town hall, the mayor tried to continue as before. He stood under the framed photograph of the tower taken before the war, his mustache waxed to points. “We will address the water,” he said, and the bell rang. He flushed. “We are discussing the water,” he amended, and the bell was silent. After that, meetings ended early. People filed out, shoes whispering.

Marta watched the square through her window. The clock tower’s face glowed milk-white at dusk. She remembered when the bell had been a novelty, when it rang for the first time in her childhood, a clear note after her father said he would be home before dark and did not mean it. He’d laughed then, too. “A trick,” he said. The bell rang again. He stopped laughing.

By autumn, the town had learned a new grammar. Notes appeared, pinned to doors. Gestures became elaborate. At the butcher’s, fingers counted cuts in the air. At the school, the teacher wrote everything on the board and erased nothing. Children stopped asking why.

Only the tower spoke.

The silence changed people’s faces. Without the cushion of lies, expressions hardened. Old arguments that had been smoothed over by years of “it’s nothing” and “don’t worry” now stood raw. Lovers broke apart without speeches. A woman packed a suitcase and left a key on the table. A man sat with his head in his hands until dawn.

Jovan began staying late at the bakery. He washed pans, folded paper bags. One evening, as Marta was sweeping, he stood in the doorway, hands jammed in his pockets. He looked at her and then at the tower. The bell was quiet, waiting.

He opened his mouth and closed it. He swallowed.

Marta felt the pressure in her chest, the words that would come if she let them. She could say something safe. She could say nothing. The bell would tell on him if he lied. It would tell on her too.

Outside, the square was empty. The air smelled like apples and cold stone.

Jovan wrote on a scrap of paper and slid it across the counter. The pencil had torn the fibers. It read: I want to leave.

Marta nodded. She wrote back: When.

He shrugged, helpless. He looked at the tower again, as if it were a judge.

She thought of the water that tasted of rust, of the mayor’s flushed face, of her father’s laugh. She thought of how much of her life had been made of things she had not said because they were easier to carry unsaid.

She said, aloud, “You should go.”

The bell did not ring.

Winter came. Snow softened the square. The clock tower wore a cap of white. People moved like ghosts, exchanging looks heavy with meaning. The bell rang less and less, not because people were truthful, but because they had stopped risking sound.

One afternoon, a stranger arrived with a satchel and a scarf wound too tight around his neck. He stood beneath the tower and spoke to the empty square. “This town is cursed,” he said, loud, and the bell rang. He laughed, surprised. “This town is blessed,” he said, and the bell rang again. He went quiet, eyes bright.

He found Marta in the bakery. He did not speak. He held out a card, on which was written, I can stop it.

Marta’s heart thudded. She gestured to a chair. He sat. She poured tea. Steam curled.

She did not ask how. She did not ask the price. She looked at the tower through the window, at the hand inching toward the hour.

She said, “If you stop it, people will lie again.”

The bell rang.

She winced, a small smile tugging her mouth. “They will speak again,” she said.

The bell was silent.

The stranger studied her, then tore the card in half and dropped it into his satchel. He stood, bowed slightly, and left without a sound.

That night, the town gathered in the square for the first time in months. No one had announced it. They came because they wanted to see if they still could.

Marta stood among them. Someone said, “I’m afraid,” and the bell rang. Someone else said, “Me too,” and the bell rang again. Laughter broke, thin and then fuller. A woman said, “I forgive you,” and the bell was silent. A man said, “I love you,” and held his breath. The bell did not ring.

When the hour came, the tower struck, as it always had, and the sound spread and settled, and the town breathed together, louder than they had in a long time.

prompt: A teacher assigns an essay on a city that no longer exists. A student claims to be from there.
story:
On Monday morning, Ms. Calder wrote the assignment on the board in her precise, looping hand: *An Essay on a City That No Longer Exists*. She paused, chalk lifted, and added beneath it, *Choose a place erased by time, disaster, or decision. Five pages. Due Friday.*

A ripple of murmurs moved through the room. Cities were easy enough—Pompeii, Troy, the drowned villages beneath reservoirs. Ms. Calder turned, dusting her hands, and launched into her usual brief lecture about memory and absence, about how history leaves footprints even when buildings are gone. She didn’t notice the boy in the third row until he raised his hand halfway, then let it fall as if it had betrayed him.

His name was Elias Morel. He had arrived three weeks into the semester with a transfer slip and a habit of sitting very still, as if the room were a photograph that might blur if he moved. He wore the same gray sweater most days, cuffs frayed, and spoke only when called on.

“Yes, Elias?” Ms. Calder said, noticing the aborted hand.

He stood instead of answering. “I’m from one,” he said. His voice was even, almost careful. “A city that no longer exists.”

A few students snorted. Someone whispered, “Atlantis,” and laughter followed, brief and sharp. Ms. Calder held up a hand. “That’s an interesting perspective,” she said. “But for the assignment, you’ll need sources.”

“I have them,” Elias said. He sat.

After class, Ms. Calder asked him to stay. The room emptied to the scrape of chairs and the thud of backpacks. Sunlight angled through the high windows, laying the desks in stripes.

“What city is this?” she asked, keeping her tone light. She had learned that teenagers sometimes wrapped grief in fantasy, that it was better not to tug too hard.

“Marrow,” he said. “It was on the coast. North of where the cliffs turn white.”

Ms. Calder frowned. She prided herself on her maps. “I don’t recall—”

“It was there,” Elias said. “Until it wasn’t.”

She nodded, a teacher’s nod that means *I hear you without agreeing*. “All right. Bring me an outline tomorrow.”

The next day, Elias handed her three pages of neat handwriting. Not an outline, she saw, but a finished draft. He had titled it simply *Marrow*. He wrote of a city built in a bowl of land, streets sloping toward a harbor like lines in a palm. He described a market that smelled of salt and fennel, a clock tower that rang a note too low, a library whose windows were always open because the air inside tasted of paper and rain. He wrote of the night the sirens failed and the sea rose without a sound, of water taking the lower streets first, then the bowl filling as if someone had tipped a cup.

There were dates, names, details that felt too specific to be invented easily. He included footnotes—oral histories, personal journals, a municipal census that ended abruptly. The sources, when she checked them that evening, led nowhere. Dead links, archives that returned errors, a census that belonged to no country.

On Wednesday, Ms. Calder brought the draft back, her margins crowded with questions. “These sources don’t exist,” she said gently. “And Marrow isn’t on any map I can find.”

Elias listened, hands folded. “It won’t be,” he said. “They took it off.”

“Who is ‘they’?”

“The same people who moved us,” he said. “Who said it was safer to forget.”

She leaned back. “Elias, if this is autobiographical—”

“It is,” he said. “I lived above the bakery. The bell stuck in winter. My mother kept the windows open in the library because she said books liked to breathe.”

The details matched the essay. Ms. Calder felt a prickle of something like unease. “If the city was destroyed,” she said, “there would be records. News. Satellite images.”

“Not when it was planned,” he said. “Not when it was a choice.”

Friday arrived. Students presented summaries of their vanished cities. Pompeii got slides. A drowned Welsh village drew sighs. When it was Elias’s turn, he stood without notes.

“Marrow was declared uninhabitable,” he said. “They said the cliffs were unstable, that the sea was rising. They moved us inland, changed our addresses, offered compensation. They built a wall and then another wall and then they opened the gates one night. In the morning, the bowl was full.”

Someone asked, “Why don’t we know about it?”

Elias looked at Ms. Calder. “Because it was easier not to,” he said. “Because the maps were redrawn and the records consolidated and the people scattered. Because a city is easier to erase than a person, and people are easier than stories.”

After class, Ms. Calder walked home along the river, the air sharp with winter. She stopped at the bridge and looked down at the water moving under her, indifferent and patient. That night, she dreamed of a city sloping toward the sea, of a clock tower ringing low.

On Monday, Elias’s desk was empty. His name remained on the roster, then didn’t. The office said there had been an error, that no such student was enrolled. Ms. Calder argued, produced the essay. The secretary shrugged. “Kids write things,” she said.

Ms. Calder went to the library, then the archives. She followed the boy’s details like breadcrumbs. A coastal plan. A canceled development. A gap in a series of maps where the paper thinned, where a place might have been and wasn’t. At the bottom of a scanned ledger, she found a note in a clerk’s hand: *Marrow—consolidated.*

She returned to her classroom and took the essay from her drawer. On the back, in pencil, Elias had written an address inland. She went there on a gray afternoon and found an apartment block identical to a hundred others. The woman who opened the door listened, then shook her head. “No,” she said. “We moved from the coast years ago. There was nothing there worth remembering.”

Ms. Calder went home and began to write. She wrote of a city in a bowl, of a bell that stuck in winter, of windows left open so books could breathe. She cited her sources carefully. She taught the story the next year, and the year after, assigning it without comment. And when students asked her where Marrow was, she said, “It was there,” and watched to see who believed her.

prompt: A musician trades their hearing for perfect pitch. Show the cost.
story:
The first sound I lost was the kettle.

It was a cheap metal thing that used to shriek like a scalded bird when the water boiled. I set it on the stove the morning after the trade, turned the knob, and waited. The kitchen light hummed—at least I assumed it did; the fluorescent tube flickered the way it always had—and the kettle sat there, mute. Steam feathered from the spout and kissed my wrist before I realized. I yelped, or thought I did, and dropped it into the sink.

I laughed, too, because the laughter was a memory of a sound, and because in my head there was an A, clean and unwavering as a plumb line. A440, like a promise kept.

Perfect pitch arrived not like a gift but like a fact. I didn’t need to strain. I knew the pitch of the refrigerator motor, the pitch of the car horn three blocks away, the pitch of the sparrow’s call outside the window—even when the world itself had gone dim. The notes existed without air. They were ideas, and ideas do not require ears.

The man in the shop had been very clear. He had smelled like dust and cloves. “You will hear everything,” he said, tapping my forehead. “But not with those.” He had smiled at my ears, pink and stupid. “And you will pay with them.”

I was thirty-one, a violinist who could tune by habit and luck but not certainty. I had lost auditions by a hair, a comma. I wanted certainty. I signed. He took my hearing with a tenderness that made my eyes water.

The first rehearsal without sound was a disaster. I showed up early, tuned my violin to itself—an act of pure arrogance, I realize now—and sat in my chair. The concertmaster nodded. Bows lifted. The orchestra moved like a single animal.

Inside me, the symphony was perfect.

I knew every pitch as it happened. The oboe’s A was 442, just a hair sharp, and the violas leaned toward it like sunflowers. The cellos lagged, rich and flat. The horns entered with a heroic G that wanted to be noble but was, today, a little tired. I knew this because the notes lit up in my mind, each one a small lantern.

What I could not do was hear the conductor’s breath before the downbeat. I could not hear the rustle of sheet music, the coughs, the collective inhale that tells you when to come in. I watched, but watching is slower than listening. I came in late. Then early. My bow scraped strings with the wrong weight because I could not feel the sound push back. The man next to me hissed something that I could not hear, his mouth a thin line.

Afterward, in the hallway, my friend Mira touched my arm and spoke. I watched her mouth, the way her lower lip caught on her teeth when she was worried. “Are you okay?” she said, I guessed.

“I’m better than okay,” I signed, clumsily. We had both learned a little for gigs in noisy places. I added, aloud, “I’m perfect.” My voice sounded wrong to me, like a stranger’s.

She hugged me, and I felt the vibration of her laugh in her chest, like a purring engine. I tried to tune to it. There was no pitch.

At home, silence became a room I lived in. The floors no longer creaked. The pipes did not complain. The rain that used to patter like a thousand fingers on the windows became only streaks of gray. In the quiet, the pitches were relentless. The clock’s tick was a precise E. The neighbor’s dog, when it barked, was a B-flat, always the same. My own heartbeat was a low, insistent thud that I could label but not hear.

I started composing.

Without sound, there was no temptation to play things I liked because they sounded nice. I built structures of pitch that were exacting and strange. I wrote a quartet that spiraled upward by commas, tightening until it broke. I wrote a solo piece that required the violinist to tune between notes the ear could barely grasp. When I brought the score to rehearsal, the players cursed me affectionately.

“This is cruel,” Mira said, smiling. I could read that one easily.

The premiere was sold out. I stood backstage and watched the audience’s mouths open and close in applause I could not hear. When the quartet began, the notes rose in my head like a cathedral. I followed along, correcting nothing, savoring everything.

At the end, there was a standing ovation. I knew because everyone stood.

Afterward, in the lobby, a woman took my hands. Her palms were dry and warm. She spoke slowly, enunciating. “I have never heard anything like that,” she said. “It hurt. In a good way.”

I nodded. Hurt I understood.

The cost came later.

It came when my mother visited and her hair had more gray than last time, and she told me about my father’s garden, and I could not hear the way she always softened his name. It came when Mira cried in the bathroom after a fight with her partner, and I could not hear the sobs that would have told me how bad it was. It came when I dropped a glass and did not know it had shattered until blood ran down my foot in bright, astonished lines.

One night, I woke from a dream of the kettle screaming and the rain drumming and my father laughing, and the silence was so complete it felt like pressure. I pressed my violin to my shoulder and drew the bow across the strings.

I felt the vibration in my bones. I knew the pitch exactly. I could build an entire world from that knowledge.

But the sound itself—the messy, imprecise, human sound—was gone.

I played until my arms ached, chasing a thing I could no longer reach, and in the perfect pitch of my mind, there was a hollow where the kettle used to scream.

prompt: A gardener finds a seed packet labeled "yesterday." They plant it anyway.
story:
The packet was wedged behind the potting bench, where spiders stitched their careful geometry and the smell of old soil lingered like a held breath. The gardener found it while looking for stakes, fingers brushing paper that was soft with age. The packet was plain brown, no illustration, no brand. In a neat hand, someone had written a single word in pencil: yesterday.

She turned it over. Nothing else. No instructions. No picture of promise. Just that word, already slipping away even as she read it.

She laughed, a small sound in the greenhouse. “Very funny,” she told the empty benches. Yesterday had been rain that came too hard, flattening the peas she’d staked too late. Yesterday had been a phone call she hadn’t returned. Yesterday had been the ache in her knees that reminded her she was no longer young enough to kneel all day without consequence.

She took the packet home anyway, slipping it into the pocket of her apron. Habit is a gardener’s second nature: save, label, wait. The garden itself was a patchwork of efforts and years—rows of garlic she’d planted in fall, the compost pile steaming like a sleeping animal, the apple tree she’d grafted with her father long before his hands shook too much to hold a knife.

That evening, after the light thinned and the birds tucked their noise into hedges, she stood at the kitchen table and opened the packet. Inside were seeds like nothing she’d planted before. They were small and dark, but not quite black—more like the color of wet pavement at dusk. They seemed heavier than their size suggested, as if they carried more than food for a future plant.

She held one to her nose. It smelled faintly of rain on warm dirt, and of something else she couldn’t name.

She slept poorly, dreams snagging and tearing. In one, she was kneeling in the garden with her father, his laugh bright and unbroken. In another, she was back at the table with the phone ringing, ringing, and she never picked it up.

In the morning, she planted them.

She chose a square of earth near the back fence, where the soil was rich and the sun forgiving. She worked carefully, opening furrows with her fingers, spacing the seeds with the same respect she gave beans and carrots. When she covered them, she pressed the soil down with her palm, feeling the cool promise beneath the surface.

As she watered, she felt a peculiar certainty, not excitement exactly, but a sense of rightness. As if she were putting something back where it belonged.

The shoots emerged quickly—too quickly. By the third day, green spears had broken the surface, trembling as if startled by light. By the end of the week, the patch was crowded with leaves that were neither round nor serrated but shaped like small, open hands.

They grew in silence. No rustle, no creak. The rest of the garden went on as gardens do, noisy with bees and wind, but the yesterday plants stood still, listening.

The first flower opened on a Tuesday. She found it in the morning, a pale bloom that looked like it had been painted rather than grown. When she leaned close, she saw that the petals were layered with fine lines, like the rings of a tree cut clean through.

She touched it.

The garden shifted.

Not in a dramatic way—no flash, no thunder. The air thickened, like humidity before a storm. The light softened. She straightened, heart knocking, and realized the apple tree’s shadow was shorter than it had been a moment before.

From the house came the sound of a door opening. A man’s voice, younger, called her name.

She knew it before she turned.

Her father stood on the porch, wiping his hands on a rag, hair still dark, shoulders broad. He smiled the way he used to, a smile that assumed time was generous.

“You’re up early,” he said.

She couldn’t speak. The garden smelled sharper, greener. The peas by the fence were standing tall, unflattened by rain that had not yet come. The ache in her knees was gone.

She spent the day in that light. They worked together, as they had when she was younger, thinning carrots, arguing amiably about compost ratios. At noon, she remembered the phone call she hadn’t returned, and returned it. The voice on the other end was surprised, then relieved.

In the afternoon, the rain came, but gentle, exactly enough.

When evening approached, the air thinned again. Her father grew translucent, the edges of him softening. He kissed her forehead, as he always had.

“Don’t forget to water,” he said, and then he was gone.

She was back in her own garden, older knees protesting as she sank to the ground. The flower was closed, the hand-shaped leaves folded in on themselves.

She understood then. The seeds did not grow tomorrow. They grew yesterday.

She went to the patch every morning after that, touching a leaf, sometimes a flower, and letting herself step back into moments she had misplaced: a friend she’d lost touch with, a choice she’d rushed, a kindness she’d withheld. She did not stay long. Yesterday was not a place to live. It was a place to visit, to tend.

The plants grew tired as summer wore on. Their leaves dulled, their stems bent. On a cool morning, she found them withered, the flowers brown and papery. She did not mourn. She dug them out and added them to the compost, returning yesterday to the work of making tomorrow possible.

In the empty square, she planted garlic. She labeled the row carefully.

She did not write yesterday. She wrote now.

prompt: A chef discovers their signature dish is used as currency. They are not pleased.
story:
By the time the third customer tried to pay for a bowl of noodles with a waxed paper packet of her food, Mira knew something had gone very wrong.

She held the packet between thumb and forefinger, careful not to smudge the oil that had seeped through. “I don’t sell these,” she said, though the words sounded thin even to her. The packet was stamped with a blue fish—her fish, the mark she burned into the counter when she’d opened the shop. Inside, she knew without opening it, were six coins of her signature dish: ember-lacquered scallops, cured and glazed until they shone like copper.

The customer, a boy with soot on his cheek, looked at her as if she were slow. “It’s worth three bowls,” he said. “Fresh.”

“Worth?” she repeated.

He nodded, serious. “You can check.”

Behind him, the lunch line had slowed to a ripple of murmurs. Someone laughed. Someone else said, “Don’t be like that, Mira.”

She set the packet down and pushed it back across the counter. “No,” she said. “I accept money.”

The boy shrugged and left the packet behind anyway, darting out into the street. Mira stood there, heart beating fast, staring at the fish stamp. When she finally tore it open, the scent rose up—smoke and sugar and sea—and her stomach clenched with a complicated ache that wasn’t hunger.

She closed the shop early.

Outside, the market was louder than usual. Hawkers called prices in singsong, but she caught other words now, threaded through: “two scallops for a loaf,” “half a packet if you hurry,” “don’t take the soft ones.” She pushed through a knot of people and saw it: a man with a wooden tray laid out like a jeweler’s case. On it, her scallops lay in neat rows, each stamped with the fish, each wrapped in waxed paper and twine. He weighed them on a scale, nodding as coins clinked into his hand—actual coins, passing for her food.

Mira felt heat climb her neck. “You,” she said.

The man looked up, mild. “Chef.”

“You’re selling my food.”

He smiled as if she’d complimented him. “Trading,” he said. “Selling would imply money mattered.”

“It does,” she said. “It matters to me.”

He gestured at the crowd. “Does it?”

She looked. A woman traded two scallops for a sack of onions. An old man handed over a packet for a bottle of lamp oil. A child counted out single pieces to buy a ribbon.

“They last,” the man said. “They keep. They’re the same every time. People trust them.”

“They’re meant to be eaten,” Mira said.

He shrugged. “Eventually.”

She went home and slept badly. She dreamed of scallops stacking themselves into walls, blocking her door.

The next morning she went to the docks. Her supplier, Len, was already there, boots slick with brine. He grinned when he saw her. “You’re famous,” he said.

“I’m ruined,” she said.

He laughed and then stopped when he saw her face. “Look, it’s not a bad thing. Your glaze—it preserves. Salt and sugar and smoke, just right. People figured it out. Better than scrip. Doesn’t rot like paper. Doesn’t lie like metal.”

“I didn’t agree,” she said.

“No one asked the wheat farmers when bread became bread,” he said gently. “Things find their use.”

She went back to the shop and shut the door. She cooked all day, hands moving on muscle memory while her thoughts chased themselves in circles. She thought of her mother teaching her the glaze, the exact moment when heat turned sticky sugar into shine. She thought of the nights she’d stayed up perfecting it, not for profit but for the pleasure of making something exact.

At dusk, someone knocked. It was the boy with soot on his cheek. He held out a coin, real this time.

“I’m sorry,” he said. “I didn’t know.”

She took the coin and then, without thinking, pressed a packet into his hand. “Eat it,” she said. “Don’t trade it.”

He smiled and ran.

The next day, she changed the recipe.

The scallops still shone, but the glaze was softer, the sugar cut with acid. They were delicious—and they bled. Oil seeped through paper, staining fingers. They dried wrong, turned sticky in heat, went dull. They wanted to be eaten while warm, now, not hoarded.

The market noticed immediately. People complained. The man with the tray scowled at her. “You’ve ruined it,” he said.

“I’ve fixed it,” she said.

Trade shifted. Some held onto old packets, relics of a shinier time, but they dwindled. Money crept back in. Mira’s shop filled with people who came to eat.

Weeks later, Len brought her a gift: a small blue ceramic fish. “For your counter,” he said.

She set it where the burn mark had been, covering the scar. The shop smelled of smoke and sugar and sea. Outside, the market sang its old songs. Inside, Mira cooked, and watched the food leave her hands and disappear into mouths, as it was always meant to.

prompt: A runner trains for a race that takes place entirely in silence. Write the day of the race.
story:
I wake before the light, before even the birds decide whether to risk it. The alarm does not ring; I have learned to wake without it. I lie still, counting my breaths, feeling the small electricity in my legs that tells me today is the day. Silence is already a room around me. It is thick as felt.

At the kitchen table I eat oatmeal and a banana. I chew slowly, mindful of the rule that begins at sunrise: no speech, no music, no unnecessary noise. Even the spoon must be set down carefully, its bowl kissed to the ceramic so it makes no mark. I think of the months I practiced this, the evenings when I turned the world down, the mornings when I ran with foam plugs sealing my ears. The coach said it would sharpen my attention. He was right. In quiet, everything has an edge.

I dress in the clothes laid out the night before. The bib number is pinned with four safety pins, their points tucked so they will not scrape me. I step into my shoes and tie the laces with small, precise movements. Outside, the sky is a pale sheet. My breath fogs, then thins. I lock the door with a twist so gentle it feels like a thought.

The start is at the old reservoir, a ring road around dark water. Runners gather in clusters, all of us with the same matte ear covers, the same neutral colors. There is a check-in tent where volunteers communicate with gestures. A hand out for the wristband. A nod. A clipboard with a tick mark. No announcements. No music. A banner at the start line reads simply: BEGIN WHEN READY. The clock stands beside it, numbers waiting to turn.

I warm up alone, jogging small loops, my feet finding their cadence. Without sound, the world presents itself differently. I notice the dew on the grass beading on my calves. I notice the way my shadow moves ahead of me, elongated, then shortens as the sun lifts. I notice my own heart as a pulse behind my ribs, a pressure rather than a beat.

At the line, I place my toes just behind the paint. Others do the same, leaving polite inches between bodies. A runner beside me touches her wristband and lifts her chin, a question. I return the nod. When I step forward, the clock begins. There is no signal, no collective surge. Each runner chooses their own beginning.

The first mile is always an argument with myself. Go easy, says one part. Go now, says another. Without the usual cues—no cheering, no slap of shoes, no breath at my ear—I must rely on the internal metronome I have built. My feet land beneath me, soft, rolling from heel to toe. The road curves gently, and the reservoir keeps its secrets, black and flat. The trees are bare, their branches like veins against the sky.

I pass a runner who is breathing hard, his mouth open. He glances at me, eyes bright, then focuses back on the road. We share a small smile, then the distance grows. There are mile markers painted on boards at the side of the road. I count them not as numbers but as stages: settle, commit, hold, risk.

At mile three, the sun crests the trees. The light strikes the water and fractures. The quiet deepens. It is not empty. It is full of things I usually miss: the way my arms swing and return, the heat building in my thighs, the taste of iron on my tongue. A thought arrives—What if I can’t keep this pace?—and I let it pass, the way you let a leaf float by without grabbing it.

By mile five, the race has sorted itself. Runners are strung out, each a moving point of effort. I am alone with my stride. The training comes back to me in flashes: the rain-soaked long run where I learned patience; the hill repeats where I learned to lean; the silent intervals on the track where I learned that pain has a shape and that shape changes if you look at it directly.

At mile seven, there is a table with cups of water. The volunteer lifts a cup, eyes meeting mine. I take it, drink, pinch the rim, and hand it back without spilling. Gratitude moves between us like a current, no words needed.

The last mile begins with a long straight. The finish is not visible yet. My legs burn. The quiet presses in, asking me to stay. This is where, in other races, the crowd would lift me, where noise would fill the gaps. Here there is only the road and my breath and the promise I made to myself months ago, scribbled in a notebook: run honestly.

I lean forward a fraction. I imagine a thread pulling me from the chest. The pain flares, then steadies. I pass one runner, then another. We exchange nods that feel like vows.

The finish appears suddenly, a simple arch, a mat on the ground. Beyond it, volunteers stand with medals, hands ready. I cross, and the clock captures my choice of beginning and my work in between. I slow to a walk, hands on my head, sweat cooling on my skin. A medal is placed around my neck. The metal rests heavy and real.

I step away and sit on the grass. The reservoir lies still. Other runners arrive, each in their own quiet moment. I close my eyes. In the absence of sound, I feel the day settle around me, complete.

prompt: A lighthouse keeper stops the light for one night. The consequences are immediate.
story:
The night the keeper turned the light off, the sea noticed before anyone else did.

Eamon Briggs stood in the lantern room with his hand on the switch, listening to the wind rake its fingers along the glass. The Fresnel lens, all prisms and patience, waited. Below him the tower’s stone spine hummed with the familiar throb of the generator. He had polished the brass at sunset, filled the oil, checked the wick even though the bulb was electric now. Habit was a hard shell.

At nine o’clock the fog slid in like a held breath. The beam should have cut it, a white blade swinging across the black water. Instead, Eamon flicked the switch down. The bulb died with a small, obedient click.

For a moment nothing happened. The fog pressed its face to the glass. Eamon felt his heart knock once, then again. He had imagined this as a quiet rebellion, a private refusal.
